{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Girish Sant | image = Girish-sant-2010.jpg | caption = Energy Analyst | birth_date = {{Birth date |df=yes|1966|1|23|}} | birth_place = [[Thane]], Maharashtra, India | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|2012|2|2|1966|1|23}} | death_place = New Delhi, India | occupation = Founder and coordinator, [[Prayas (Energy Group)]] | alma_mater = [[IIT Bombay]] | nationality = Indian | parents = | awards = }} '''Girish Sant''' was a noted energy analyst held in high esteem as an energy policy commentator from India. He co-founded the non-governmental organisation Prayas in Pune, India. His analytical inputs helped shape India's energy policy over the decades of the 1990s and 2000s. He was considered an effective team builder and mentored several energy researchers and activists.
== Formative years== Girish spent his childhood in [[Thane]], and joined [[IIT Bombay|IIT Mumbai]] in 1982 for BTech in [[Chemical engineering]]. After completing BTech in 1986, he also completed Masters in Energy Systems in 1988 from IIT.
Girish's years in [[IIT Bombay|IIT Mumbai]] brought out his leadership, team building and [[mountaineering]] skills. He was an accomplished mountaineer and rock climber, and made important [[rock climbing]] ascents with fellow mountaineers including the first ever climb of the [[Harishchandragad#Konkan Kada (Konkan cliff)|Konkan Kada]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Girish Sant|url=http://ajayshahblog.blogspot.in/2012/02/girish-sant.html|publisher=Ajay Shah|accessdate=12 December 2013}}</ref> He was an active member of the IIT Mountaineering Club and also the Institute Mountaineering Secretary during 1985–86.
During his stay at IIT, particularly during his Masters study, Girish started thinking about full-time work in a field of direct social relevance along with friends – Ajit Gaunekar and Aniruddha Ketkar. He started interacting with Subodh Wagle, then research fellow at Center for Technology Alternatives for Rural Areas, with whom he explored [[appropriate technologies]], rural society and related developmental paradigms.<ref name="smriti">{{cite book|title=Girish Sant-Always Two Steps Ahead|url=http://www.prayaspune.org/peg/images/stories/Pub_Pictures/Event/Girish%20Sant%20-%20Always%20Two%20Steps%20Ahead.pdf|publisher=Prayas|year=2013}}</ref>
== Entry to the energy sector== By 1988, when Girish completed Masters in [[Electric power system|energy systems]], he developed a clear idea that he wanted to work for the betterment of society and not for personal prosperity, using his professional skills on issues related to energy.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Girish Sant|url=http://www.epw.in/commentary/girish-sant.html|journal=Economic and Political Weekly|volume=XLVII|issue=10|date=10 March 2012|author=Prayas Energy Group}}</ref> He relocated to Pune and initially worked as a lecturer in an engineering college, undertook sporadic energy audit and industrial consultancy projects and then worked at [[Systems Research Institute (India)|Systems Research Institute]]. This was a period of exploration along with other like-minded friends – Shripad Dharmadhikary, Sanjeevani and Vinay Kulkarni – that brought him closer to people's movements, particularly the [[Narmada Bachao Andolan|NBA]].
During this period he came across the Development Focused End Use Oriented (DEFENDUS)<ref>{{cite web|title=Energy Paradigm|first=Amulya|last=Reddy|url=http://www.amulya-reddy.org.in/Publ_421_E_EP.htm|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> approach to power sector planning developed by Prof. Amulya Kumar N. Reddy. Subsequent interactions with Prof. Reddy shaped his thinking and work in the energy sector in the early period.<ref>{{cite journal|title=A Critique of DEFENDUS|url=http://www.epw.in/discussion/critique-defendus.html|journal=Economic and Political Weekly|volume=XXVII|issue=41|author1=Girish Sant |author2=Shripad Dharmadhikari |date=10 October 1992}}</ref> By this time, Girish started working with Shantanu Dixit who continued to be his colleague for the rest of his life. Analytical motivation from DEFENDUS, along with the support of friends and a scholarship from [[Ashok Gadgil|Dr. Ashok Gadgil]], led to his first major work on development of a least cost plan for Maharashtra.<ref>{{cite report|title=Least-Cost Power Planning: Case Study of Maharashtra State|url=http://prayaspune.org/peg/publications/item/89-least-cost-power-planning-case-study-of-maharashtra-state.html|publisher=Prayas|author1=Girish Sant |author2=Shantanu Dixit }}</ref> Development of the least cost plan, its dissemination to various quarters and subsequent responses from power sector actors and activists contributed to his understanding of the energy sector and the broader political economy and institutional dynamics of the sector in India.
This was also the time of reforms for the power sector in India, which witnessed entry of projects such as [[Dabhol Power Station|Dabhol Power Company]] built by [[Enron]]. Girish, Subodh and Shantanu were able to see the long term implications of such projects and reforms for the Indian power sector and economy at large. Realising the need to de-mystify such complex projects and to highlight their implications for people of the state and the country, they worked relentlessly to unravel the complex [[power purchase agreement]] of Enron and communicate the devastating impact of the project to activists and the wider community.<ref>{{cite report|title=The Enron Controversy: Techno-Economic Analysis and Policy Implications|url=http://www.prayaspune.org/peg/publications/item/91-the-enron-controversy-techno-economic-analysis-and-policy-implications.html|publisher=Prayas|author1=Girish Sant |author2=Shantanu Dixit |author3=Subodh Wagle |date=September 1995}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Dabhol Project PPA-Structure and Techno-Economic Implications|url=http://www.epw.in/special-articles/dabhol-project-ppa-structure-and-techno-economic-implications.html|journal=Economic and Political Weekly|volume=XXX|issue=24|author1=Girish Sant |author2=Shantanu Dixit |author3=Subodh Wagle |date=17 June 1995}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|chapter=The Power Purchase Agreement|title=Power Play|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PXNADUzQL_8C&pg=PA97&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=4|first=Abhay|last=Mehta|publisher=Orient Longman}}</ref> These early experiences shaped his vision for the power sector as well as his strategic and substantive approach to work in the energy sector.
== Formation of prayas, institution building and approach to policy analysis== [[File:Girish Sant 2002.jpg|thumb|Girish Sant at New Rajendra Nagar in New Delhi, January 2002]]
In 1994, his work in the energy sector evolved into the formation of Prayas, Initiatives in Health, Energy, Learning and Parenthood<ref>{{cite web|title=About Girish|url=http://prayaspune.org/peg/about-girish.html|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> along with Sanjeevani and Vinay Kulkarni.<ref>{{cite web|title=Organizational History|url=http://www.prayaspune.org/health/index.php/home/about-us/organizational-history.html|publisher=Prayas, Health Group|accessdate=23 January 2014}}</ref>
Girish believed in and ensured teamwork and democratic working of the group. Under his leadership, the [[Prayas (Energy Group)|Energy Group within Prayas (PEG)]], which started with three people, expanded to a team of over 15 researchers from a variety of backgrounds. Girish had the ability to connect with a wide range of professionals, which attracted senior researchers as well as young engineers to join Prayas.<ref>{{cite web|title=People|url=http://prayaspune.org/peg/prayas-energy-group/people.html|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref>
Girish was particular about encouraging intellectual and substantive growth of colleagues, and supported new initiatives in the form of Resources and Livelihoods group of Prayas as well as academic interests of young researchers. Girish paid meticulous attention to the internal processes within Prayas and ensured that proper procedures were followed. Many peers and friends of Girish consider his institution building abilities as important a contribution and achievement as his substantive work in the energy sector.<ref name="tributes">{{cite web|title=Tributes|url=http://www.prayaspune.org/peg/tributes.html|publisher=Prayas, Energy Group|accessdate=27 January 2014}}</ref> Girish assisted the likes of Sucheta Dalal, then a columnist in the Times of India, in understanding the controversial [[Dabhol Power Company|Dabhol power project]] and the [[Enron scandal|Enron India scam]] that they unearthed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Girish Sant memorial lecture 2015|website=www.youtube.com|publisher=Prayas (Energy group)|accessdate=28 October 2016}}</ref>
Girish emphasised the need to be agile and to undertake strategic interventions in the sector. High quality and in-depth analysis, comprehensive approach, and prioritising interests of disadvantaged sections became the hallmark of his work and he successfully cultivated these principles across PEG. He believed that improving governance in infrastructure sectors like energy has the dual advantage of improving lives of the poor as well as saving public money that can then be spent on other services such as education. He successfully motivated and actively supported many young researchers to take up the task of policy advocacy in the energy sector based on public interest analysis.<ref>{{cite journal|title=मी-आम्ही-आमचॅ काम अजुन चालतॊचि वाट...|journal=Mauj|language=Marathi|first=Girish|last=Sant|date=November 2004|publisher=Mauj Prakashan}}</ref><ref>{{cite AV media|people=E. A. S. Sarma|title=Economic Development and Energy Planning-The Myths and the Realities|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IRy6ns2uzSo|medium=Public Lecture|publisher=Girish Sant Memorial Committee|location=Pune, India|year=2013}}</ref>
In spite of several accomplishments and achieving an important stature in the energy sector in India, Girish remained humble and self-effacing, as is reflected in many of the tributes on his memorial webpage and in the Smriti Grantha (or Collection of Memoirs). He was mild mannered and soft-spoken, even when trying to convince someone holding a contrary opinion. This quality endeared him to many in the sector resulting in increased impact.<ref name="smriti" /><ref name="tributes" />
== Interventions in the electricity sector== Girish was known in the energy sector for his use of high quality analysis to expose inadequacies of conventional planning and projects that result out of such a process. Under his guidance, PEG undertook techno-economic analysis of three large [[hydro-electric]] projects, Sardar Sarovar and Maheshwar in India and Bujagali in Uganda. The group analysed Sardar Sarovar and Maheshwar projects and highlighted inefficiencies therein, proposing several techno-economically feasible and socially desirable alternatives.<ref>{{cite report|title=Towards an Efficient and Low Cost Power Sector|url=http://prayaspune.org/peg/publications/item/100.html|author1=Girish Sant |author2=Shantanu Dixit |publisher=Prayas|date=September 1998}}</ref> Analysis of [[Bujagali Hydroelectric Power Station]] brought out inflated capital costs and one-sided nature of the power purchase agreement and led to renegotiation of the contract.<ref>{{cite report|title=The Bujagali Power Purchase Agreement – an Independent Review|url=http://prayaspune.org/peg/publications/item/115.html|publisher=Prayas|date=November 2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Rethinking Bujagali|url=http://www.internationalrivers.org/resources/rethinking-bujagali-3338|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref>
The wave of independent power producers in the 1990s was followed by State Electricity Board (SEB) reforms supported by the [[World Bank]] and [[Asian Development Bank]], starting from Orissa in 1996. Under these reforms unbundling the SEB into generation, transmission and distribution companies, setting up a regulatory commission and gradually privatising the distribution was presented as the solution to all problems in power sector.<ref>{{cite report|title=Report on Infrastructural Development|chapter=Power|url=http://indiaimage.nic.in/pmcouncils/reports/infra/ichap3.htm|publisher=Prime Minister's Council on Trade and Industry|accessdate=28 January 2014}}</ref> PEG was the first to prepare a public interest critique of the Orissa model of reforms in 1998 and the role of Multi-lateral Development Banks, arguing that democratising governance is the key to addressing the power sector crisis, rather than focusing only on infusing capital or changing ownership.<ref>{{cite journal|title=WB-Orissa Model of Power Sector Reform-Cure Worse Than Disease|url=http://www.epw.in/commentary/wb-orissa-model-power-sector-reform-cure-worse-disease.html|publisher=Economic and Political Weekly|volume=XXXIII|issue=17|author1=Girish Sant |author2=Shantanu Dixit |author3=Subodh Wagle |date=25 April 1998}}</ref><ref>{{cite report|title=Power Sector Restructuring: Challenges, Lessons, and Suggestions|url=http://prayaspune.org/peg/publications/item/97.html|publisher=Prayas|author1=Girish Sant |author2=Shantanu Dixit |author3=Subodh Wagle |date=January 1998}}</ref><ref>{{cite report|title=Accountability: The Real Crisis in the Power Sector Left Unaddressed|url=http://prayaspune.org/peg/publications/item/98.html|publisher=Prayas|author1=Girish Sant |author2=Shantanu Dixit |author3=Subodh Wagle |date=January 1998}}</ref><ref>{{cite report|title=Regaining Rationality through Democratisation: A Critical Review of Multilateral Development Banks’ (MDBs’) Power Sector Activities in India|url=http://prayaspune.org/peg/publications/item/103.html|publisher=Prayas|author1=Girish Sant |author2=Shantanu Dixit |author3=Subodh Wagle |date=May 1999}}</ref>
PEG realised that the fight against unjust, inefficient projects needs to be started at the macro-level planning stage itself. Experience of disseminating least cost plan and struggle against Enron project,<ref>{{cite journal|title=Godbole Committee on Enron Project|url=http://www.epw.in/special-articles/godbole-committee-enron-project.html|publisher=Economic and Political Weekly|volume=XXXVI|issue=23|author=Prayas Energy Group|date=9 June 2001}}</ref> highlighted the influence of political economy on decision making and underscored the need for improving governance through enhanced transparency, accountability and participation (TAP) in the energy sector decision making. These insights have since guided the group's work in the energy sector and led to the group undertaking early interventions in improving the newly emerging independent regulatory commissions.<ref>{{cite conference|title=Regulation: Case Study of Power Sector Privatisation in India|url=http://prayaspune.org/peg/publications/item/96.html|author=Prayas|series=World Bank-NGO Consultation on Privatization|date=September 1997}}</ref> Girish provided strategic guidance on the initial idea of bringing together a transnational network of civil society groups, called the Electricity Governance Initiative, that would work together to advance the principles of transparent, inclusive and accountable governance of electricity.<ref>{{cite web|title=Remembering Girish Sant|url=http://electricitygovernance.wri.org/news/2012/02/remembering-girish-sant|publisher=World Resources Institute|accessdate=3 February 2013}}</ref>
Girish was keen that analysis is followed by actual interventions aimed at pro-people changes. Accordingly, PEG actively engaged with several state as well as central regulatory commissions, with the aim of making [[Regulatory Processes|regulatory process]] more transparent, accountable, participatory and helped serve the public interest more effectively.<ref>{{cite letter|subject=Second Tariff Revision Proposal by MSEB|url=http://prayaspune.org/peg/publications/item/110.html|last=Prayas|first=Energy Group|recipient=MERC|date=November 1999}}</ref> Subsequent to enactment of Electricity Act 2003, PEG was actively involved in giving inputs to national policies such as National Electricity Policy, Tariff Policy and Competitive Bidding Guidelines. This analysis of the Indian power sector and its role in the regulatory process was acknowledged by many in the sector.<ref>{{cite book|chapter=Preface|title=Governing Power|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X4-GRtXOTrcC&pg=PP21&source=gbs_selected_pages&cad=3|author=S L Rao|publisher=TERI Press}}</ref>
== Work beyond the electricity sector== [[File:Girish Sant 2011.png|thumb|Girish Sant at a UN Climate Change Workshop, 2011]]Since 2006, Girish focused more on macro issues of resource availability, utilisation, and growing importance of global climate debate on India's energy policy. In 2009, he co-authored a report, 'An Overview of India's Energy Trends', highlighting important differences in energy production and [[Energy consumption|consumption]] trends of India, US, European Union and China.<ref>{{cite report|title=An overview of Indian Energy Trends: Low Carbon Growth and Development Challenges|url=http://www.prayaspune.org/peg/publications/item/74-an-overview-of-indian-energy-trends-low-carbon-growth-and-development-challenges.html|publisher=Prayas|author1=Girish Sant |author2=Narasimha Rao |author3=Sudhir Chella Rajan |date=September 2009}}</ref> Based on this work, he was invited to make presentations at high level meetings at [[COP15]] at [[Copenhagen]] and at [[The Center for Clean Air Policy]], Washington, D.C.<ref>{{cite interview|title=Pre-Copenhagen Interview at the Center for Clean Air Policy|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8e6VPqBzjOY|accessdate=16 January 2014}}</ref> He was India's representative at a UN workshop on non-Annex 1 [[Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Action|NAMA]]s.<ref>{{cite conference|url=http://unfccc2.meta-fusion.com/kongresse/110403_AWG_Bangkok/templ/play.php?id_kongresssession=3466&theme=unfccc |title=United Nations Climate Change Conference Pre-sessional Workshops |location=[[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]] |date=3–8 April 2011 |accessdate=29 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203034912/http://unfccc2.meta-fusion.com/kongresse/110403_AWG_Bangkok/templ/play.php?id_kongresssession=3466&theme=unfccc |archivedate=3 February 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Subsequently, he was one of India's representatives in the [[BASIC countries|BASIC]] Expert Group (an informal energy expert group formed by BASIC governments) that worked towards developing greater understanding of energy use in BASIC countries and for evolving common approach to climate negotiation.<ref>{{cite book|title=Equitable Access to Sustainable Development-Contribution to the body of scientific knowledge|url=http://www.erc.uct.ac.za/Basic_Experts_Paper.pdf|publisher=BASIC expert group|year=2011|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite interview|title=Interview with Girish in the context of Durban Climate Change Conference|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DYxLKwSrHBk|date=2011|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> All these efforts and analysis contributed to strengthening India's position in the global discourse on climate change and energy, and also helped shape the domestic policy discourse.
On the domestic front, while welcoming the investment in renewable energy (RE), Girish suggested measures to improve effectiveness and equity in RE expansion.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Need to Realign India's National Solar Mission|url=http://www.epw.in/special-articles/need-realign-indias-national-solar-mission.html|journal=Economic and Political Weekly|volume=XLV|issue=12|author1=Ranjit Deshmukh |author2=Girish Sant |author3=Ashwin Gambhir |date=20 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=India's Solar Mission: Procurement and Auctions|url=http://www.epw.in/commentary/indias-solar-mission-procurement-and-auctions.html|journal=Economic and Political Weekly|volume=XLVI|issue=28|author1=Ashwin Gambhir |author2=Girish Sant |author3=Ranjit Deshmukh |date=9 July 2011}}</ref> He was instrumental in making a case for setting up a National Wind Energy Mission, which is scheduled to begin in 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=First National Wind Energy Mission to begin by mid-2014|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2014-01-08/news/45991703_1_wind-sector-generation-based-incentive-wind-power|agency=Times of India|date=8 January 2014|accessdate=29 January 2014}}</ref>
Search for innovative solutions to vexed problems was another characteristic of Girish. This search led to a unique and novel concept for improving efficiency of commonly used domestic appliances. Though Girish and several other researchers had pointed out that energy efficiency of commonly used domestic appliances is very poor and using most efficient appliances instead of these inefficient appliances will lead to savings of thousands of MWs, a workable large scale solution to achieve this transformation was elusive.<ref>{{cite report|title=Strategic Actions for Rapid Implementation of Energy Efficiency|url=http://prayaspune.org/peg/publications/item/156.html|publisher=Prayas|author1=Daljit Singh |author2=Girish Sant |date=June 2011}}</ref> Girish, along with colleagues at Prayas, developed a concept called 'Super-Efficient Equipment Program – SEEP' under which nominal incentives are provided to appliance manufacturers to bring super-efficient equipment into the market.<ref>{{cite report|title=Development of Super Efficient Equipment Programme ( SEEP ) for Fans|url=http://www.prayaspune.org/peg/publications/item/175-development-of-super-efficient-equipment-programme-seep-for-fans.html|publisher=Prayas|author1=Daljit Singh |author2=Girish Sant |author3=Aditya Chunekar |author4=Adwait Pednekar |author5=Shantanu Dixit |date=July 2012}}</ref> He successfully convinced [[Government of India]] and [[Planning Commission (India)|Planning Commission]] officials of the benefits of implementing such a program.<ref>{{cite news|title=12th Plan to focus on energy conservation|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/industry-and-economy/article2400309.ece|agency=The Hindu Business Line|date=26 August 2011|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref> Under this program, which will be launched in 2014{{update inline|date=December 2015}} as part of the [[12th Five Year Plan (Government of India)|12th Five Year Plan]], it is expected that over five million 'super-efficient' fans, which consume half the electricity of normal fans, will be sold in the market. This approach is also being adopted at the global level under the auspices of the [[Clean Energy Ministerial]].<ref>{{cite book|title=SEEP Guidebook|url=http://www.prayaspune.org/peg/publications/item/241-seep-guidebook-advance-draft-version.html|date=April 2013}}</ref>
Girish was also part of several official committees, such as Planning Commission's working groups for 11th and 12th five-year plans, Planning Commission's Steering Committee on Energy, the Supreme Court appointed Committee on Solid Waste Disposal, and Planning Commission's Expert Group on Low Carbon Strategies for Inclusive Growth.<ref>{{cite web|title=Engagement in Policy Related Committees|url=http://www.prayaspune.org/peg/contributions-recognition.html|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref>
== Death== Girish died on 2 February 2012 in New Delhi due to cardiac arrest.<ref>{{cite news|title=Power sector expert Sant dies of cardiac arrest|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-02-04/pune/31024432_1_renewable-energy-cardiac-arrest-power-sector|agency=Times of India|date=4 February 2012}}</ref>
A committee consisting of people from within and outside Prayas was formed to manage activities organised in Girish's memory and "to further his work of independent analysis and advocacy to promote public interest issues in the energy sector". These activities include an annual memorial lecture organised in Pune and a fellowship for young researchers pursuing public interest research and advocacy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Memorial|url=http://www.prayaspune.org/peg/memorial.html|accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref>
== Membership in policy related committees== # Member, BASIC Expert Group (2011–12) # Convener Transport Working Group, of The Expert Group appointed by The [[Planning Commission (India)]] in 2010, to work out the 'Low Carbon Strategy for Inclusive Growth’ # Member, [[World Bank]] Expert Committee to review [[West Bengal]] Power Sector Reforms (2008) # Member, 'Working Group on Power' for formulation of XIth five-year plan for the National [[Planning Commission (India)]] (2006–07) # Member, Expert Group, convened by Secretary of Power ([[Government of India]]) to seek "radical" policy suggestions (2006) # Member Expert Group on "Financing access to basic utilities for all" formed by the [[Friedrich Ebert Foundation]] in co-operation with the [[Financing for Development]] Office, June 2006. # Member, Expert Committee appointed by The [[Supreme Court of India]] for evaluating 'Waste to Energy projects from [[Municipal Solid Waste]]', appointed through [[Ministry of Non-Conventional Energy Sources]] (2005–06) # Member, Central Advisory Committee of [[Central Electricity Regulatory Commission]] ([[India]]), since 1998 till 2010 # Member, State Advisory Committee of [[Maharashtra Electricity Regulatory Commission]], since 1999 till 2010 # Member, 'Consultative Group on Power & Energy' of [[Planning Commission (India)]] for review of energy sector performance in the Xth plan # Member, Advisory Committee, [[Asian Development Bank|ADB]] Policy Research Network to strengthen policy reforms – Infrastructure Development for Poverty Reduction: Priorities, Constraints and Strategies (2004–05) # Member, Western Regional Energy Committee Confederation of Indian Industries (CII) (2003 and 2004) # Member Advisory Committee, Distribution Reforms Upgrade Management (DRUM) program of [[Government of India]] and [[USAID]] (2003) # Member, Study Group on Benefits of [[Sardar Sarovar Dam]] Project, [[Government of Maharashtra]] (2001) # Member, Task Force to review Narmada Dams, [[Government of Madhya Pradesh|Government of M.P.]] (1998) # Member, International team of civil society to review status of rehabilitation of project affected persons at by Coal mines and Thermal plants at Singrauli (UP) (1995)
== Recognition== # Dr. T. N. Khoshoo Memorial Award in 'Conservation, Environment and Development' for year 2010, – Ashoka Trust for Research in Ecology and the Environment (Bangalore)<ref>{{cite web|title=T N Khoshoo Memorial Award 2010|url=http://www.atree.org/KhoshooAward?quicktabs_kmaal_qt=0#21|accessdate=12 December 2013}}</ref> # 'Best Energy Alumni' – Energy Department, [[IIT Bombay]] (2008). # 'Life Time Achievement – Encouragement Award' – Workers' and Engineers' union of Power utility in Maharashtra (2003), which he accepted on behalf of [[Prayas (energy group)]] # As a student, received citation for 'Exceptional Contribution Award' for enhancing Mountaineering activity at [[IIT Bombay]]. # 'Annual Girish Sant Memorial Lecture' – [[IIT Bombay]]<ref>{{cite web|title=1st Annual Girish Sant Memorial Lecture|url=http://www.ese.iitb.ac.in/content/first-girish-sant-memorial-lecture|publisher=IIT, Bombay|accessdate=12 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=1st Annual Girish Sant Memorial Lecture – Recording and Transcript|url=https://archive.org/details/1stAnnualGirishSantMemorialLecture-IitBombay|accessdate=12 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2nd Annual Girish Sant Memorial Lecture|url=http://www.iitb.ac.in/fcseminars/stlecture/IC18Sept2013.pdf|publisher=IIT, Bombay|accessdate=12 December 2013}}</ref> # Dedication of the book "Churning the Earth"<ref>{{cite book|chapter=Dedication|title=Churning the Earth: The Making of Global India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AAx7r1SdYt0C&pg=PT5&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=4|authors=Ashish Kothari, Aseem Shrivastava|publisher=Penguin}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} '''Global strategic petroleum reserves''' ('''GSPR''') refer to [[Petroleum|crude oil]] inventories (or stockpiles) held by the government of a particular country, as well as private industry, to safeguard the economy and help maintain [[national security]] during an [[energy crisis]].
According to the United States [[Energy Information Administration]], approximately {{convert|4.1|Goilbbl|m3}} of oil are held in strategic reserves, of which 1.4 billion is government-controlled. The remainder is held by private industry. In 2004 the U.S. [[Strategic Petroleum Reserve (United States)|Strategic Petroleum Reserve]] had the largest strategic reserve, with much of the remainder held by the other 27 members of the [[International Energy Agency]].<ref>{{cite news|title= Fact Sheet on IEA Oil Stocks and Emergency Response Potential |publisher= International Energy Agency|date=2004-01-01 |url=http://www.iea.org/textbase/papers/2004/factsheetcover.pdf}}</ref> Some non-IEA countries have started work on their own strategic petroleum reserves. China has the largest of these new reserves.
Global oil consumption is in the region of {{convert|0.1|Goilbbl|m3}} per day.<ref>https://{{cite web|url=https://www.eia.gov/forecasts/steo/report/global_oil.cfm|title=Short-Term Energy Outlook |publisher= U. S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)|date= February 9, 2016}}</ref> The 4.1 bbl reserve is equivalent to 41 days of production. If there ever is a dramatic fall in global output, as envisaged by some [[peak oil]] analysts, the strategic petroleum reserves might be used to cover the shortfall. Covering a 50% shortfall would deplete the reserves in 82 days, although export leaders the [[Middle East]] and [[Russia|Russian]] exports represent only 22% and 6% respectively of global production.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/resources/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2242rank.html|title=Crude Oil - Exports |publisher= Central Intelligence Agency - The World Factbook|accessdate= 17 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/resources/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2241rank.html|title=Crude Oil - Production |publisher= Central Intelligence Agency - The World Factbook|accessdate= 17 May 2016}}</ref>
==International Energy Agency reserves== According to a March 2001 agreement, all 28 members of the [[International Energy Agency]] must have a strategic petroleum reserve equal to 90 days of the previous year's net oil imports for their respective countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iea.org/Textbase/work/2002/beijing/KUOLT2.PDF |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-12-29 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161105032856/http://www.iea.org/Textbase/work/2002/beijing/KUOLT2.PDF |archivedate=5 November 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>[https://archive.is/20120721230353/http://www.agiweb.org/gap/legis106/reauthspr.html Reauthorization of the Energy Policy & Conservation Act<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Only net-exporter members of the IEA are exempt from this requirement. The exempt countries are [[Canada]], [[Denmark]], [[Norway]], and the [[United Kingdom]]. However, the UK and Denmark recently drew up plans to create their own strategic reserves in order to meet their legal obligations as [[European Union]] member states. This agreement was reviewed and ratified by Steven Brown in 2008.
==Forward commercial storage agreements== To allow oil-exporting countries increased flexibility in their production quotas, there has been a progressive movement towards forward commercial storage agreements. These agreements allow petroleum to be stored within an oil-importing country. However, the reserves are technically under the control of the oil-exporting country. Such agreements enable oil-importing countries to access these commercial reserves in a timely and cost effective way.
==Emergency oil sharing agreements== Several countries have agreements to share their stockpiles with other countries in the event of an emergency.
===The Japan, New Zealand and South Korea agreement=== In 2007, Japan announced a plan to share its strategic reserves with other countries in the region. Negotiations are under way between Japan and New Zealand for an oil-sharing deal whereby Japan sells part of its strategic reserves to New Zealand in the event of an emergency. New Zealand would be required to pay the market price for the oil, plus negotiated option fees for the amount of oil previously held for them by Japan.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.rigzone.com/news/article.asp?a_id=49325 RIGZONE - Article Not Found<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304191114/http://www.rigzone.com/news/article.asp?a_id=49325 |date=4 March 2016 }}</ref>
South Korea and Japan have agreed to share their oil reserves in the event of an emergency.<ref>[http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/06/18/business/AS-FIN-SKorea-Japan-Oil.php South Korea, Japan agree to share oil reserves - International Herald Tribune<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212201429/http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/06/18/business/AS-FIN-SKorea-Japan-Oil.php |date=12 February 2009 }}</ref>
===The United States and Israel agreement=== According to the 1975 [[Second Sinai withdrawal document]] signed by the United States and Israel, in an emergency the U.S. is obligated to make oil available for sale to Israel for a period of up to five years.<ref>[http://www.heritage.org/Research/MiddleEast/bg76.cfm The Iranian Oil Crisis<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100126173509/http://www.heritage.org/Research/MiddleEast/bg76.cfm |date=26 January 2010 }}</ref>
===The France, Germany, and Italy agreement=== France, Germany and Italy have an oil-sharing agreement in place that allows them to buy oil from each other in the event of an emergency.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> In 1968, the six members of the European Economic Community – Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands – agreed to maintain a minimum level of crude oil stocks and oil products corresponding to 65 days' worth of domestic consumption. In 1972, this obligation was raised to 90 days.<ref>http://www.l20.org/publications/16_rk_ES_Jacoby.pdf{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Africa==
===Kenya=== [[Kenya]] is setting up a Strategic Fuel Reserve, similar to that of cereals. The stocks would be procured by the [[National Oil Corporation of Kenya]] and stored by the [[Kenya Pipeline Company]] Limited.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200804281577.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-25 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121005154612/http://allafrica.com/stories/200804281577.html |archivedate=5 October 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
===Malawi=== [[Malawi]] is considering creating a 22-day reserve of fuel, which is an expansion from the current five-day reserve. The government is planning to build storage facilities in the provinces of [[Chipoka]] and [[Mchinji]] as well as [[Kamuzu International Airport]].<ref>[http://www.nyasatimes.com/index.php?news=1915 Nyasa Times - Malawi breaking news, sports, showbiz, jobs, business and social networking - Malawi to increase fuel storage<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090211215524/http://www.nyasatimes.com/index.php?news=1915 |date=11 February 2009 }}</ref>
===South Africa=== [[South Africa]] has an SPR managed by [[PetroSA]]. The main facility is the [[Saldanha Bay]] oil storage facility, which is a major transit point for oil shipping.<ref>[http://www.southafrica.info/doing_business/economy/key_sectors/energy.htm South Africa's energy industry - SouthAfrica.info<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20061128224017/http://www.southafrica.info/doing_business/economy/key_sectors/energy.htm |date=28 November 2006 }}</ref> Saldanha Bay's six in-ground concrete storage tanks give the facility a storage capacity of {{convert|45000000|oilbbl}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fred.csir.co.za/www/sff/oil.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-07-24 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304001840/http://fred.csir.co.za/www/sff/oil.htm |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Asia==
===China=== {{Main|Strategic Petroleum Reserve (China)}} In 2007, China announced the expansion of its crude reserves into a two-part system. China's reserves would consist of a government-controlled strategic reserve complemented by mandated commercial reserves.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinanews.cn/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-11-12 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120512051835/http://chinanews.cn/ |archivedate=12 May 2012 |df=dmy }}/news/2007-07-19/37721.html</ref> The government-controlled reserves are being completed in three stages. Phase one consisted of a {{convert|101900000|oilbbl}} reserve, mostly completed by the end of 2008. The second phase of the government-controlled reserves with an additional {{convert|170000000|oilbbl}} was to be completed by 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gulfnews.com/business/Oil_and_Gas/10272815.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227130102/http://www.gulfnews.com/business/Oil_and_Gas/10272815.html |archivedate=27 February 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref> Recently, [[Zhang Guobao]], head of the National Energy Administration, stated that there will be a third phase that will expand reserves by {{convert|204000000|oilbbl}} with the goal of increasing China's SPR to 90 days of supply by 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinasourcingblog.org/2009/10/chinas-energy-security-strateg.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160419044338/http://www.chinasourcingblog.org/2009/10/chinas-energy-security-strateg.html |archivedate=19 April 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref>
The planned state reserves of {{convert|475900000|oilbbl}} together with the planned enterprise reserves of {{convert|209440000|oilbbl}} will provide around 90 days of consumption or a total of {{convert|684340000|oilbbl}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationmaster.com/graph/ene_oil_con-energy-oil-consumption |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-08 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140209230523/http://www.nationmaster.com/graph/ene_oil_con-energy-oil-consumption |archivedate=9 February 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref>
===India===
{{Main|Strategic petroleum reserve (India)}}
In 2003, [[India]] started development on a strategic crude oil reserve<ref name="businesstoday.intoday.in">{{cite web|url=http://businesstoday.intoday.in/story/several-large-infrastructure-projects-new-government/1/205851.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-09 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706175909/http://businesstoday.intoday.in/story/several-large-infrastructure-projects-new-government/1/205851.html |archivedate=6 July 2015 |df=dmy }}</ref> sized at {{convert|37400000|oilbbl}}, enough to provide two weeks of consumption.<ref>[http://www.gasandoil.com/goc/news/nts43834.htm Alexander's Gas & Oil Connections - India to build up storage of crude oil<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418001150/http://www.gasandoil.com/goc/news/nts43834.htm |date=18 April 2009 }}</ref> Petroleum stocks have been transferred from the [[Indian Oil Corporation]] (IndianOil) to the [[Oil Industry Development Board]] (OIDB).<ref>[http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/2006/04/02/stories/2006040202220200.htm The Hindu Business Line : Strategic oil reserves to come directly under Govt<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212181220/http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/2006/04/02/stories/2006040202220200.htm |date=12 February 2009 }}</ref> The OIDB then created the Indian Strategic Petroleum Reserves Ltd (ISPRL) to serve as the controlling government agency for the strategic reserve.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/India_to_form_crude_oil_reserve_of_5_mmt/articleshow/2137148.cms | work=The Times Of India | title=News By Industry | date=2007-06-20}}</ref>
The facilities are located at: *[[Mangalore]], State of [[Karnataka]]. Capacity of {{convert|10.995|Moilbbl|m3}}. *Padur village, [[Udupi]] in the state of [[Karnataka]]. Capacity of {{convert|18.7|Moilbbl|m3}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.deccanherald.com/deccanherald/apr42005/national153423200543.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-03-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070218140645/http://www.deccanherald.com/deccanherald/apr42005/national153423200543.asp |archivedate=18 February 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref> *[[Visakhapatnam]], State of [[Andhra Pradesh]]. Capacity of 1.33 million tonnes.<ref name="businesstoday.intoday.in"/>
On 21 December 2011, a senior oil ministry official announced that India was planning to augment its crude reserve capacity to 132 million barrels by 2020.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204464404577111893998225190 | work=The Wall Street Journal | title= India Unveils Ambitious New Strategic Oil Stockpile Plans | date=2011-12-21}}</ref>
===Japan === [[File:Shibushi Oil Stockpile Site 2009.JPG|thumb|250px|Japan [[Shibushi, Kagoshima|Shibushi]] Oil Stockpile Site]] As of 2010, [[Japan]] has an SPR composed of the following three types of stockpiles: * State-controlled reserves of petroleum at 11 different locations totaling {{convert|324000000|oilbbl}}. <small>''All numbers, unless otherwise cited, come from p. 177 of this document: [http://www.iea.org/textbase/nppdf/free/2000/oilsecu2001.pdf]''</small> **[[Tomakomai]] Eastern Oil Reserve Storage Base – 55 storage tanks, total capacity {{convert|34|Moilbbl|m3}}. **[[Mutsu-Ogawara]] Storage Base – 53 storage tanks, total capacity {{convert|31|Moilbbl|m3}}. **[[Kuji]] Storage Base – three storage tanks, total capacity {{convert|10.5|Moilbbl|m3}}. **[[Akita, Akita|Akita]] Storage Base – 15 storage tanks, total capacity {{convert|23.4|Moilbbl|m3}}. **[[Fukui, Fukui|Fukui]] Storage Base – 27 storage tanks, total capacity {{convert|17.9|Moilbbl|m3}}. **[[Kikuma]] Underground Petroleum Storage Facility – eight storage tanks, total capacity {{convert|8.9|Moilbbl|m3}}. **[[Shirashima]] Storage Facility – eight tankers ({{convert|4400000|oilbbl}} each), total capacity {{convert|35.2|Moilbbl|m3}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/country/1998/9314098.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-03-13 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303171614/http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/country/1998/9314098.pdf |archivedate=3 March 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref> **[[Kamigotou]] Storage Base – seven storage tanks, total capacity {{convert|21.45|Moilbbl|m3}}. **[[Kushikino]] Storage Base – three storage tanks, total capacity {{convert|10.5|Moilbbl|m3}}. **[[Shibushi, Kagoshima|Shibushi]] Storage Base – 40 storage tanks, total capacity {{convert|27.6|Moilbbl|m3}}. **[[Kagoshima]] – {{convert|4.0|Moilbbl|m3}}. A '''forward commercial storage facility''' with [[Abu Dhabi]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenational.ae/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID%3D%2F20100227%2FBUSINESS%2F702279924%2F1137 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304024145/http://www.thenational.ae/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20100227%2FBUSINESS%2F702279924%2F1137 |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref> * Private reserves of petroleum held "in accordance with the [[Petroleum Stockpiling Law]]" of {{convert|129000000|oilbbl}}.<ref>[http://www.enecho.meti.go.jp/english/energy/japan/oilinfo.html The Oil Situation after the Attack on Iraq<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070222122752/http://www.enecho.meti.go.jp/english/energy/japan/oilinfo.html |date=22 February 2007 }}</ref> * Private reserves of petroleum products for another {{convert|130000000|oilbbl}}. The state-controlled reserves and the privately held stockpiles total about {{convert|583000000|oilbbl}}.<ref>{{cite news|title= Energy Security in East Asia |publisher= Institute for the Analysis of Global Security|date=2004-08-13 |url=http://www.iags.org/n0813042.htm}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title= Energy Security Initiative |publisher= Asia Pacific Energy Research Center |date= 2002-01-01 |url= http://www.ieej.or.jp/aperc/2002pdf/OilStocks2002.pdf |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060620092529/http://www.ieej.or.jp/aperc/2002pdf/OilStocks2002.pdf |archivedate= 20 June 2006 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> The Japanese SPR is run by the [[Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corporation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jogmec.go.jp/english/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161002021744/http://www.jogmec.go.jp/english/index.html |archivedate=2 October 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref>
===South Korea=== In South Korea, refineries, specified distributors, and importers, are obliged to hold from 40 days to 60 days of their daily import, sale, or refined production, based on the previous 12 months. At the end of 2010, South Korea possessed a total storage capacity of 286 million barrels (45.5 million cubic meters), composed of 146 mb of South [[Korea National Oil Corporation]]'s facilities used for government stocks and international joint oil stockpiling, and 140 mb used for industry operation and mandatory industry stocks.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/Korea_OSS2011.pdf | publisher=www.iea.org | title=Oil and Gas Emergency Policy - Korea 2011 update | date=2011-12-21}}</ref> South Korea's oil stocks in terms of days of net imports have consistently been above 160 days since January 2009, hitting the country’s historical record of 240 days (124 days of government stocks and 117 days of industry stocks) in March 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.iea.org/netimports.asp| publisher=www.iea.org | title=Closing Oil Stock Levels in Days of Net Imports | date=2014-03-14}}</ref>
===Others=== The [[Philippines]] had plans for a National Petroleum Strategic Reserve by 2010 with an approximate size of {{convert|30000000|oilbbl}}.<ref>[http://www.energybulletin.net/8226.html Energy conservation takes center stage in the Philippines | EnergyBulletin.net | Peak Oil News Clearinghouse<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080603002501/http://www.energybulletin.net/8226.html |date=3 June 2008 }}</ref>
[[Singapore]] does not have any oil reserves.
[[Republic of china|Taiwan]] has an SPR with a 1999-reported size of {{convert|13000000|oilbbl}}.<ref>{{cite news|title= Improving Energy Security Through an International Cooperative Approach to Strategic Oil Stocks |publisher= International Energy Agency|date=2003-09-19 |url=http://www.iea.org/textbase/work/2003/berlin/leiby.pdf}}</ref> Taiwan's refiners (Kaohsiung {{convert|270000|oilbbl/d|abbr=on}}; Ta-Lin {{convert|300000|oilbbl/d|abbr=on}}; Tao-Yuan {{convert|200000|oilbbl/d|abbr=on}}; Mailiao 150,000 bbl/d) are also required to store at least 30 days of petroleum stocks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/taiwan.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061215030951/http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/taiwan.html |archivedate=15 December 2006 |df=dmy }}</ref> As of 2005, these mandated commercial reserves total {{convert|27600000|oilbbl}} of strategic petroleum stocks.
[[Thailand]] increased the size of its SPR from 60 days to 70 days of consumption in 2006.<ref>[http://www.bruneitimes.com.bn/section/opinion/26Dec2006-4.php The Brunei Times<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928041209/http://www.bruneitimes.com.bn/section/opinion/26Dec2006-4.php |date=28 September 2007 }}</ref>
[[Pakistan]] has announced plans for a 20-day emergency reserve.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/the-newspaper/front-page/plan-for-20day-oil-stocks-to-avert-shortage-100 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-10-13 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101013073835/http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/the-newspaper/front-page/plan-for-20day-oil-stocks-to-avert-shortage-100 |archivedate=13 October 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Europe==
===European Union=== In the [[European Union]], according to [[Council Directive]] 68/414/EEC of 20 December 1968, all 28 member states are required to have a strategic petroleum reserve within the territory of the E.U. equal to at least 90 days of average domestic consumption.<ref>{{cite news |title= Council Directive 68/414/EEC of 20 December 1968 imposing an obligation on Member States of the EEC to maintain minimum stocks of crude oil and/or petroleum products |publisher= European Union |date= 1968-12-20 |url= http://europa.eu/scadplus/leg/en/lvb/l27045.htm |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060826233332/http://europa.eu/scadplus/leg/en/lvb/l27045.htm |archivedate= 26 August 2006 |df= dmy-all }}</ref>
The [[Czech Republic]] has a four-tank SPR facility in [[Nelahozeves]] run by the company CR Mero.<ref name=autogenerated4>[http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/NC_Europe/Oil.html North Central Europe] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107135246/http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/NC_Europe/Oil.html |date=7 January 2009 }}</ref> The Czech SPR is equal to 100 days of consumption or {{convert|20300000|oilbbl}}.<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite news |url=http://www.globalinsight.com/SDA/SDADetail8001.htm |title=European Leaders Fire Up Over Russian Oil Cut |publisher=[[Global Insight]] |date=2007-01-10 |accessdate=2007-01-10 }}</ref>
[[Denmark]] has a reserve equal to 81 days of consumption (about 1.4 million tonnes).<ref>[http://www.ens.dk/da-DK/UndergrundOgForsyning/Forsyningssikkerhed/Beredskab_for_oliekriser/Danskberedskab/Sider/Forside.aspx Danish Agency for Energy] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219003422/http://www.ens.dk/da-DK/UndergrundOgForsyning/Forsyningssikkerhed/Beredskab_for_oliekriser/Danskberedskab/Sider/Forside.aspx |date=19 February 2012 }}</ref> Not counting reserves held by the military defence.
[[Finland]] has an SPR with an approximate size of {{convert|62400000|oilbbl}}.<ref>[http://english.people.com.cn/200509/09/eng20050909_207507.html People's Daily Online - Finland decides to tap strategic oil reserves in Katrina aftermath<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605232200/http://english.people.com.cn/200509/09/eng20050909_207507.html |date=5 June 2011 }}</ref>
[[France]] has an SPR with an approximate size of {{convert|65000000|oilbbl}}.<ref>[http://www.ambafrance-us.org/news/statmnts/2005/oilreserve_katrina_090205.asp Embassy of France in the US - katrina - Strategic oil reserves <<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929083828/http://www.ambafrance-us.org/news/statmnts/2005/oilreserve_katrina_090205.asp |date=29 September 2007 }}</ref> As of 2000, jet fuel stocks for at least 55 days of consumption were required, with half of those stocks controlled by the ''Société Anonyme de Gestion des Stocks de Sécurité'' (SAGESS) and the other half controlled by producers.<ref name=autogenerated3>{{cite web|url=http://www.iea.org/textbase/nppdf/free/2000/oilsecu2001.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-03-13 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303200450/http://www.iea.org/textbase/nppdf/free/2000/oilsecu2001.pdf |archivedate=3 March 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref>
[[Germany]] created the Federal Oil Reserve in 1970, located in the Etzel salt caverns near [[Wilhelmshaven]] in northern Germany, with an initial size of {{convert|70|Moilbbl|m3}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www0.gsb.columbia.edu/faculty/ghubbard/Articles%20for%20Web%20Site/Managing%20the%20Strategic%20Petroleum%20Reserve_Energy%20Policy%20in%20a%20.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-03-09 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160629203910/https://www0.gsb.columbia.edu/faculty/ghubbard/Articles%20for%20Web%20Site/Managing%20the%20Strategic%20Petroleum%20Reserve_Energy%20Policy%20in%20a%20.pdf |archivedate=29 June 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref> The current German Federal Oil Reserve and the Erdölbevorratungsverband (EBV) (the German stockholding company) mandates that refiners must keep 90 days of stock on hand, giving Germany an approximate reserve size of {{convert|250000000|oilbbl}} as of 1997.<ref>[http://www.pennwellpetroleumgroup.com/Articles/Article_Display.cfm?ARTICLE_ID=114993&Section=ARTCL GERMANY - Online Research Center<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929000803/http://www.pennwellpetroleumgroup.com/Articles/Article_Display.cfm?ARTICLE_ID=114993&Section=ARTCL |date=29 September 2007 }}</ref> The German SPR is the largest in Europe.
[[Hungary]] has an SPR equal to approximately 90 days of consumption or {{convert|11880000|oilbbl}}.<ref>[http://www.abcmoney.co.uk/news/6200783775.htm Hungarian govt releases strategic oil reserves after Russian supply cut-off<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927203259/http://www.abcmoney.co.uk/news/6200783775.htm |date=27 September 2007 }}</ref>
[[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] has approximately 31 days of oil stocks in Ireland and another nine days of oil stocks held in other [[European Union|EU]] members states. Additionally, it has stock tickets (contracts with a third party whereby the government has the option of purchasing oil in the event of an emergency) and stocks held by large industry or large consumers. In total, Ireland has approximately 100 days' worth of oil at its disposal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dcenr.gov.ie/Energy/Oil+Supply+Division/Ireland+s+Current+Stock+Levels.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-09-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120062015/http://www.dcenr.gov.ie/Energy/Oil%2BSupply%2BDivision/Ireland%2Bs%2BCurrent%2BStock%2BLevels.htm |archivedate=20 November 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>http://www.nora.ie/{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The [[Netherlands]] maintains a stockpile equal to 90 days of net oil imports. In 2013, this was about four million tonnes of oil.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.government.nl/issues/energy-policy/oil |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150821035856/http://www.government.nl/issues/energy-policy/oil |archivedate=21 August 2015 |df=dmy }}</ref>
[[Poland]] has an SPR equal to approximately 70 days of consumption.<ref>https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20070108/ap_on_bi_ge/belarus_russia_oil_5{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Another facility holding 20 days of consumption was completed in 2008. Poland also requires oil companies to maintain reserves sufficient to provide 73 days of consumption.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/rbssEnergyNews/idUSL354313120080903?rpc=401& | work=Reuters | title=Poland mulls oil reserve changes for refiners | date=2008-09-03}}</ref>
[[Portugal]] has an SPR with an approximate size of {{convert|22440000|oilbbl}}.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_kmafp/is_200509/ai_n15327212 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080107102957/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_kmafp/is_200509/ai_n15327212 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2008-01-07 | work=AFP | title=Portugal to tap oil reserves to help hurricane-ravaged US | date=2005-09-01 }} </ref>
[[Slovakia]] has an SPR with an approximate size of {{convert|748000|oilbbl}}.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
[[Spain]] has an SPR with an approximate size of {{convert|120000000|oilbbl}}.<ref>Staff Writer. "[http://www.elmundo.es/mundodinero/2005/09/08/economia/1126166131.html El Consejo de Ministros aprueba el envío del 2% de las reservas de crudo para ayudar a EEUU] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160323130621/http://www.elmundo.es/mundodinero/2005/09/08/economia/1126166131.html |date=23 March 2016 }}." ''[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]].'' 9 September 2005. Retrieved on 10 June 2006. Article in [[Spanish language|Spanish]].</ref>
[[Sweden]] has an SPR with an approximate size of {{convert|13290000|oilbbl}}.<ref>[http://english.people.com.cn/200509/16/eng20050916_208886.html People's Daily Online - Swedish government releases gasoline reserves<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605232223/http://english.people.com.cn/200509/16/eng20050916_208886.html |date=5 June 2011 }}</ref>
The [[United Kingdom]] recently drew up plans to create its own strategic fuel reserves utilizing Steven Brown as an agreement agent.
===Russia=== As of 2011, Russia is accumulating strategic reserves of refined oil products to be held by [[Rosneftegaz]], a state-owned company. The reserves will be held at commercial refineries, Transneft facilities and state reserve facilities. The current planned size is {{convert|14665982|oilbbl}}.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/13/russia-oil-reserves-idUSLDE76C0JZ20110713?rpc=401&feedType=RSS&feedName=rbssEnergyNews&rpc=401 | work=Reuters | title=UPDATE 2-Russia to build state fuel stocks to ease shortages | date=2011-07-13}}</ref>
===Switzerland=== [[Switzerland]] has SPRs consisting of gas, diesel, jet fuel and heating oil for 4.5 months of consumption. The reserves were created in the 1940s.
==Middle East==
===Iran=== In April 2006, the Fars News Agency reported that [[Iran]] was planning to create an SPR. The [[National Iranian Oil Company]] (NIOC) began construction of 15 crude oil storage tanks with a capacity of {{convert|10000000|oilbbl}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/Iran/pdf.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002211847/http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/cabs/Iran/pdf.pdf |archivedate=2 October 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref> In August 2008, Iran announced plans to expand the SPR with a new facility on [[Kharg Island]] with four tanks holding {{convert|1000000|oilbbl}} each. Iran's SPR facilities are: *[[Ahwaz]] – four storage tanks, total capacity {{convert|2|Moilbbl|m3}}. *[[Omidiyeh]] – three storage tanks, total capacity {{convert|3|Moilbbl|m3}}. *[[Goureh]] – six storage tanks, total capacity {{convert|4|Moilbbl|m3}}. *[[Sirri Island]] – one storage tank, total capacity {{convert|500000|oilbbl|m3}}. *[[Bahregansar]] – one storage tank, total capacity {{convert|500000|oilbbl|m3}}. *[[Kharg Island]] – four storage tanks, total capacity {{convert|4|Moilbbl|m3}}. (Planned facility, not operational yet.)
===Kuwait=== [[Kuwait]] has a joint stockpile located in [[South Korea]]. The deal gives South Korea first rights to purchase the oil. As of 2006, the size of the stockpile is {{convert|2|Moilbbl|m3}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.knoc.co.kr/ENG/sub04/sub04_1_5.jsp|title=Joint Stockpiling with Kuwait|publisher=[[Korea National Oil Corporation]]|access-date=2 November 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120407203602/http://www.knoc.co.kr/ENG/sub04/sub04_1_5.jsp|archivedate=7 April 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Israel=== As of 1975, [[Israel]] is believed to have a strategic oil reserve equal to 270 days of consumption.
===Jordan===
Jordan has strategic oil reserves equal to 60 days of consumption or {{convert|6240000|oilbbl}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tradeportalofindia.com/contentmgmt/Desktops2.asp?itemcode%3DI484%26compid%3Ditpo |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-07-13 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303183228/http://www.tradeportalofindia.com/contentmgmt/Desktops2.asp?itemcode=I484&compid=itpo |archivedate=3 March 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==North America==
===United States=== {{Main|Strategic Petroleum Reserve (United States)}} The [[United States]] has the world's largest reported [[Strategic Petroleum Reserve (United States)|Strategic Petroleum Reserve]] with a total capacity of 727 million barrels. If completely filled, the U.S. SPR could theoretically replace about 60 days of oil imports. The U.S. is estimated to import approximately {{convert|12000000|oilbbl/d}} of crude oil.<ref>See [[Strategic Petroleum Reserve (United States)]]</ref> According to the U.S. Department of Energy, the facilities' maximum flow rate is limited to approximately {{convert|4400000|oilbbl/d}} when filled to maximum capacity, declining as the reserve is emptied.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fe.doe.gov/programs/reserves/spr/spr-facts.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130428130222/http://www.fe.doe.gov/programs/reserves/spr/spr-facts.html |archivedate=28 April 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> The reserves are kept in salt caverns located at: * Bryan Mound – near [[Freeport, Texas]]. Capacity of {{convert|226000000|oilbbl}}. * Big Hill – near [[Winnie, Texas]]. Capacity of {{convert|160000000|oilbbl}}. * West Hackberry – near [[Lake Charles, Louisiana]]. Capacity of {{convert|219000000|oilbbl}}. * Bayou Choctaw – near [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana]]. Capacity of {{convert|72000000|oilbbl}}. * [[Richton, Mississippi]]. A planned facility.
The U.S. also has the {{convert|2|Moilbbl|m3|sing=on}} [[Northeast Home Heating Oil Reserve]] to supply northeast home owners with heating oil if there is a shortage.
==Oceania== As of 2008, [[New Zealand]] has a strategic reserve with a size of 170,000 tons or {{convert|1200000|oilbbl}}. Much of this reserve is based upon ticketed option contracts with Australia, Japan, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands, which allow for guaranteed purchases of petroleum in the event of an emergency.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/oilRpt/idUKT20877720071227?rpc=401& | work=Reuters | title=Nippon Oil sells emergency oil reserves option to NZ | date=2007-12-27}}</ref>
As of 2008, [[Australia]] holds three weeks of petroleum, instead of the allotted 90 days that was agreed upon, according to the study 'Liquid Fuel Security' authored by [[Air Vice-Marshal]] John Blackburn, AO (retired).
==See also== {{Portal|Energy}}
*[[Energy development]] *[[Energy security]] *[[Peak oil]] *[[Strategic reserve]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== For more on APEC strategic reserves: * https://web.archive.org/web/20060421064534/http://pzl1.ed.ornl.gov/APECSizeIAEEPaperFinal_Proceedings.pdf * https://web.archive.org/web/20060620092529/http://www.ieej.or.jp/aperc/2002pdf/OilStocks2002.pdf For more info on the IEA reserves: * http://www.iea.org/dbtw-wpd/Textbase/work/2003/asean/CZECH.PDF

revision.comment: Removing link(s): [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Mike Hopkins (business)]] closed as delete ([[WP:XFDC|XFDcloser]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Ice Energy | logo = | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | industry = [[Energy storage]] | founded = {{start date|2003}} | hq_location_city = [[Santa Barbara, California]] | hq_location_country = United States | area_served = [[California]] | key_people = {{ublist |Mike Hopkins ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]]) |James White ([[Chief financial officer|Chief Financial Officer]]) |Greg Miller ([[Executive Vice President|EVP]], Market Development)|Brandon McNeil ([[Executive Vice President|EVP]], Operations)}} | products = Ice Bear | owner = Pacific Advantage Capital | num_employees = | website = {{URL|ice-energy.com}} }} '''Ice Energy''' is an [[energy storage]] company serving [[utility companies]] in [[California]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=St. John|first1=Jeff|title=Ice Energy Finds Profits in Thermal Energy Storage|url=http://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/ice-energy-finds-profits-in-thermal-energy-storage|accessdate=8 January 2015|work=Greentech Grid|publisher=Greentech Media, Inc.|date=20 June 2012}}</ref> Its main product is the Ice Bear system, developed for small to mid-sized commercial buildings.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cordner|first1=Christine|title=SoCalEd's energy storage winners say RFO results legitimize the resource|url=https://www.snl.com/InteractiveX/Article.aspx?cdid=A-29840877-11812|accessdate=8 January 2015|work=SNL|publisher=SNL Financial LC|date=14 November 2014}}</ref> The Ice Bear freezes water at night when electricity is cheaper and uses that ice for space cooling during the day.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wald|first1=Matthew|title=Energy-Storage Plans Gain Ground in California|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/22/business/energy-environment/california-picks-energy-storage-over-some-new-power-plant-bids.html?module=Search&mabReward=relbias%3Aw%2C{%222%22%3A%22RI%3A18%22}&_r=2|accessdate=21 January 2015|work=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=21 December 2014}}</ref>
== History ==
Ice Energy was founded in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|last1=St. John|first1=Jeff|title=SCE Chooses Ice Energy for 25MW of Rooftop Thermal Energy Storage|url=http://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/SCE-Chooses-Ice-Energy-for-25MW-of-Rooftop-Thermal-Energy-Storage|website=Greentech Grid|publisher=Greentech Media, Inc.|accessdate=19 January 2015}}</ref> In August 2014, Ice Energy revealed a version of the Ice Bear for single-family homes called the Ice Cub.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Handova|first1=Derek|title=Ice Tech Enables Time-Shifting for Single-Family House Cooling|url=https://medium.com/@DerekHandova/ice-tech-enables-time-shifting-for-single-family-house-cooling-3551f7855972|website=Medium|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref> In November, the company won sixteen contracts with [[Southern California Edison]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Richardson|first1=Jake|title=25 MW Of Ice Energy Storage For Southern California Edison|url=http://cleantechnica.com/2014/11/22/25-mw-ice-energy-storage-southern-california-edison/|website=Clean Technica|publisher=Sustainable Enterprises Media, Inc.|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Welter|first1=Ben|title=Ice Energy lands 16 contracts with Southern California Edison|url=http://www.puretemp.com/pcmatters/ice-energy-lands-16-contracts|website=PureTemp|publisher=Entropy Solutions, LLC|accessdate=12 January 2015}}</ref> The contracts totaled 25.6 megawatts.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Trabish|first1=Herman|title=Big storage procurements leave more questions than answers|url=http://www.utilitydive.com/news/big-storage-procurements-leave-more-questions-than-answers/333031/|website=Utility Dive|publisher=Industry Dive|accessdate=20 January 2015}}</ref>
== See also ==
* [[Energy storage]] * [[List of energy storage projects]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.ice-energy.com}}
[[Category:Energy storage]] [[Category:Energy companies of the United States]] [[Category:Energy in California]] [[Category:Companies based in Santa Barbara, California]] [[Category:American companies established in 2003]] [[Category:Energy companies established in 2003]] [[Category:2003 establishments in California]]

page.title: List of Lepidoptera that feed on clovers

revision.text:
'''[[Clover]]s''', ''Trifolium'' species, are used as food plants by the [[caterpillar]]s of a number of [[Lepidoptera]] (butterflies and moths), including:
==[[phagy|Monophagous]]== [[Species]] which feed exclusively on ''Trifolium''
* [[Coleophoridae]] ** Several ''[[Coleophora]]'' case-bearer species: *** ''[[Coleophora argentifimbriata|C. argentifimbriata]]'' *** ''[[Coleophora deauratella|C. deauratella]]'' – only on [[red clover]] (''T. pratense'') *** ''[[Coleophora mayrella|C. mayrella]]'' – only on [[white clover]] (''T. repens'') *** ''[[Coleophora spissicornis|C. spissicornis]]''
==[[phagy|Polyphagous]]== Species which feed on ''Trifolium'' and other plants
* [[Coleophoridae]] ** Several ''[[Coleophora]]'' case-bearer species: *** ''[[Coleophora alcyonipennella|C. alcyonipennella]]'' *** ''[[Coleophora frischella|C. frischella]]'' – recorded on white clover (''T. repens'') * [[Crambidae]] ** ''[[Dolicharthria punctalis]]'' * [[Gelechiidae]] ** ''[[Chionodes lugubrella]]'' – recorded on white clover (''T. repens'') * [[Geometridae]] ** ''[[Ectropis crepuscularia]]'' (engrailed) ** ''[[Eupithecia centaureata]]'' (lime-speck pug) ** ''[[Eupithecia pusillata]]'' (juniper pug) – Americas only ** ''[[Odontopera bidentata]]'' (scalloped hazel) ** ''[[Semiothisa clathrata]]'' (latticed heath) * [[Hepialidae]] ** ''[[Wiseana cervinata]]'' * [[Hesperiidae]] ** ''[[Pyrgus malvae]]'' (grizzled skipper) – recorded on red clover (''T. pratense'') * [[Lymantriidae]] ** ''[[Euproctis chrysorrhoea]]'' (brown-tail) * [[Noctuidae]] ** ''[[Agrotis clavis]]'' (heart and club) ** ''[[Agrotis segetum]]'' (turnip moth) ** ''[[Axylia putris]]'' (flame) ** ''[[Discestra trifolii]]'' (nutmeg) ** ''[[Euxoa nigricans]]'' (garden dart) ** ''[[Ochropleura plecta]]'' (flame shoulder) ** ''[[Schinia jaguarina]]'' (jaguar flower moth) ** ''[[Xestia c-nigrum]]'' (setaceous Hebrew character) * [[Zygaenidae]] ** ''[[Zygaena filipendulae]]'' (six-spot burnet)
== External links == *[http://www.nhm.ac.uk/our-science/data/hostplants/search/list.dsml?searchPageURL=index.dsml&PGenus=Trifolium&sort=Taxon "Search Results - Hostplant Genus: ''Trifolium''"] at ''HOSTS - a Database of the World's Lepidopteran Hostplants'' of the Natural History Museum, London. Retrieved 8 October 2017.
[[Category:Lists of Lepidoptera by food|Clover]] [[Category:Trifolium|+Lepidoptera]]

'''List of Salticidae species T–V''' includes all described species with a scientific name starting from T to V of the spider family [[Salticidae]] as of December 18, 2016.<ref>{{cite web |date=2016 |url=http://www.wsc.nmbe.ch/family/83/Salticidae |title=Family: Salticidae |work=World Spider Catalog |version=17.5 |publisher=Natural History Museum Bern |accessdate=2016-12-18 }}</ref>

The following is a '''list of [[Sites of Special Scientific Interest]] in the [[Western Isles North]]''' [[Area of Search]]. For Western Isles South see [[List of SSSIs in Western Isles South]]. For SSSIs elsewhere in [[Scotland]], see [[List of SSSIs by Area of Search]].

{{short description|A list of former oceans that disappeared due to tectonic movements and other geographical and climatic changes}} This is a list of former [[ocean]]s that disappeared due to [[plate tectonics|tectonic movements]] and other geographical and climatic changes. In alphabetic order:
*[[Bridge River Ocean]], the ocean between the ancient [[Insular Islands]] (i.e. [[Stikinia]]) and North America *[[Cache Creek Ocean]], a Paleozoic ocean between the Wrangellia Superterrane and Yukon-Tanana Terrane *[[Iapetus Ocean]], the southern hemisphere ocean between [[Baltica]] and [[Avalonia]] *[[Khanty Ocean]], the Precambrian to Silurian ocean between Baltica and the [[Siberia (continent)|Siberian continent]] *[[Mezcalera Ocean]], the ocean between the Guerrero terrane and [[Laurentia]] *[[Mirovia]], the ocean that surrounded the [[Rodinia]] supercontinent *[[Mongol-Okhotsk Ocean]], the early Mesozoic ocean between the [[North China Craton|North China]] and [[Siberia]] cratons *[[Oimyakon Ocean]], the northernmost part of the Mesozoic Panthalassa Ocean *[[Paleo-Tethys Ocean]], the ocean between [[Gondwana]] and the Hunic terranes *[[Pan-African Ocean]], the ocean that surrounded the [[Pannotia]] supercontinent *[[Panthalassa]], the vast world ocean that surrounded the [[Pangaea]] supercontinent, also referred to as the [[Paleo-Pacific Ocean]] *[[Pharusian Ocean]], Neoproterozoic *[[Poseidon Ocean]], Mesoproterozoic *[[Pontus Ocean]], the western part of the early Mesozoic Panthalassa Ocean *[[Proto-Tethys Ocean]], Neoproterozoic *[[Rheic Ocean]], the Paleozoic ocean between Gondwana and [[Laurussia]] *[[Slide Mountain Ocean]], the Mesozoic ocean between the ancient [[Intermontane Islands]] (i.e. [[Wrangellia]]) and North America *[[South Anuyi Ocean]], Mesozoic ocean related to the formation of the Arctic Ocean *[[Tethys Ocean]], the ocean between the ancient continents of Gondwana and [[Laurasia]] *[[Thalassa Ocean]], the eastern part of the early Mesozoic Panthalassa Ocean *[[Ural Ocean]], the Paleozoic ocean between Siberia and Baltica
==See also== *{{annotated link|Paratethys}} *{{annotated link|Piemont-Liguria Ocean}} *{{annotated link|Superocean}}, an ocean that surrounds a global [[supercontinent]] *{{annotated link|Valais Ocean}}
[[Category:Oceans|ancient oceans]] [[Category:Oceanography|ancient oceans]] [[Category:Proterozoic paleogeography]] [[Category:Paleozoic paleogeography]] [[Category:Mesozoic paleogeography]]

{{italic title}} '''''Mammal Species of the World: A Taxonomic and Geographic Reference''''' is a standard reference work in [[mammalogy]] giving descriptions and [[Bibliographic database|bibliographic data]] for the known species of [[mammal]]s. It is now in its third edition, published in late 2005, which was edited by [[Don E. Wilson]] and DeeAnn M. Reeder.<ref>{{MSW3}}</ref>
An online version is hosted by [[Bucknell University]], from which the names of the species can be downloaded as a custom dictionary. A partial online version is available at Google Books (see "External links" below).
The Checklist Committee is charged with compiling and updating MSW. In its Annual Report for 2015, the Committee noted that it is under contract with Johns Hopkins Press for the 4th edition of MSW, which will be edited by DeeAnn M. Reeder and Kristofer M. Helgen. The database has been made editable for the authors, leading to more frequent website updates. The publication was due in 2017.<ref>[http://www.mammalsociety.org/uploads/report_files/Checklist%20Committee_0.pdf Checklist Committee 2015]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
