revision.text:
{{Infobox comics creator | image = Marc Sleen 675.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Sleen in 2012 | birth_name = Marcel Neels | birth_date = 30 December 1922 | birth_place = [[Gentbrugge]], [[East Flanders]], Belgium | death_date = {{nowrap|{{death date and age|2016|11|6|1922|12|30|df=y}}}} | death_place = [[Hoeilaart]], [[Flemish Brabant]], Belgium | nationality = Belgian | area = Artist, writer | alias = Marc Sleen | notable works = ''[[The Adventures of Nero|Nero]]''
''[[De Lustige Kapoentjes]]''
''[[Piet Fluwijn en Bolleke]]''
''[[Oktaaf Keunink]]''
''[[Doris Dobbel]]''
''[[De Ronde van Frankrijk]]'' | awards = [[#Awards|full list]] }} '''Marcel Honoree Nestor, ''[[Ridder (title)|ridder]]''[[Ridder (title)|Ridder]] is a noble title given by the reigning monarch and commonly added between the first names and last name. It is not part of the birth name. ''Ridder'' is roughly equivalent with Knight. Neels''' (30 December 1922 – 6 November 2016), known as '''Marc Sleen''', was a Belgian [[cartoonist]]. He was mostly known for his comic ''[[The Adventures of Nero|The Adventures of Nero and Co.]]'', but also created gag comics like ''[[Piet Fluwijn en Bolleke]]'', ''[[De Lustige Kapoentjes]]'', ''[[Doris Dobbel]]'', ''[[Oktaaf Keunink]]'' and ''[[De Ronde van Frankrijk]]''. Sleen was one of the most celebrated comics artists in his home country. His work is admired for its absurd and sometimes satirical comedy, as well for the fact that he worked completely singlehandedly without any assistance for 45 years on end, a feat that landed him a spot in ''[[The Guinness Book of Records]]'' in 1992.{{cite book|last1=Magnussen|first1=Anne|title=Comics & Culture: Analytical and Theoretical Approaches to Comics|date=2000|publisher=Museum Tusculanum Press|isbn=9788772895802|page=102}}{{cite web|title=Marc Sleen|url=https://www.lambiek.net/artists/s/sleen.htm|website=Lambiek Comiclopedia|accessdate=7 November 2016}} (This feat has been surpassed since by [[Jim Russell (cartoonist)|Jim Russell]]'s ''[[The Potts]]'', which ran for 62 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/longest-running-cartoon-strip-by-a-single-artist|title=Longest running cartoon strip by a single artist|publisher=}}) He was one of the few comics artists in Belgium who had a museum dedicated to his work.{{cite news|title=Marc Sleen krijgt eigen museum in Brussel|url=http://www.nieuwsblad.be/cnt/dmf17062009_055|accessdate=7 November 2016|agency=Belga|publisher=Nieuwsblad|language=Dutch}} ==Biography== Marc Sleen was born as Marcel Neels in [[Gentbrugge]], near [[Ghent]].De Weyer, Geert (2005). "Marc Sleen". In België gestript, pp. 160–161. Tielt: Lannoo. He studied drawing in Ghent. During the [[Second World War]] he was imprisoned by Nazi soldiers in [[Fort Breendonk]] because his brother worked for the resistance. He was tortured and put in the death cell, but saved by the fact that after [[D-Day]] the officers moved all the prisoners to a different prison, where he could escape. In 1944 he started to work as a political caricaturist in the Flemish newspaper ''[[De Standaard]]''. He also contributed illustrations and short comics for the newspaper and the youth supplement, and made illustrations and his first comics for the magazine ''Ons Volk''.{{cite news|title=BIOGRAFIE. Marc Sleen, geestelijke vader van dagbladverschijnsel Nero|url=http://www.gva.be/cnt/dmf20161107_02559524/biografie-marc-sleen-geestelijke-vader-van-dagbladverschijnsel-nero|agency=Belga|publisher=Gazet van Antwerpen|date=7 November 2016|language=Dutch}} In October 1947, Marc Sleen started a new series, ''The adventures of detective Van Zwam'' in the newspaper ''De Nieuwe Gids''. In the first adventure [[Detective Van Zwam]] encounters a fool who thinks he is emperor [[Nero]]. After he regains his senses, they continue calling him Nero and slowly he became the star of the series. The name changes accordingly to ''The adventures of detective Van Zwam and Nero'' and after nine stories to ''The adventures of Nero and co''. The series appeared for 55 years with a rhythm of two strips every day. This was typical for the Flemish comic tradition, as with ''[[Suske en Wiske]]'' (''Spike and Suzy''). ''Nero'' became well known for its [[irony|ironic]] [[humour]] and references to current affairs. For instance, in the album, ''Het Vredesoffensief Van Nero'' ("Nero's Peace Offensive") (1951), Nero visits [[Joseph Stalin]] to make him drink an elixir that will make him a [[pacifism|pacifist]]. Besides ''Nero'' Sleen drew many other comic strip series, many of them [[gag-a-day]] comics, for magazines like ''[['t Kapoentje]]'' and ''[[Ons Volkske]]''. Among the most well known were ''[[Piet Fluwijn en Bolleke]]'' (1947–1965), ''[[Doris Dobbel]]'' (1950–1965), ''[[Oktaaf Keunink]]'' (1952–1965) and ''[[De Lustige Kapoentjes]]''. Sleen also drew a daily cartoon during the [[Tour de France]] from 1947 until 1965, called ''[[De Ronde van Frankrijk]]''. [[File:Nero in Antwerpen.jpg|thumb|Wall painting in [[Antwerp]] showing the main characters of ''Nero'']] Between 1950 and 1965 Sleen published ''Nero'' in ''[[Het Volk (newspaper)|Het Volk]]'', after which he moved to ''[[De Standaard]]''. This caused a huge copyright controversy, as several newspapers fought over the rights over his syndicated comics. Thousands of readers switched from ''Het Volk'' to ''De Standaard'', just to follow his adventures in the newspaper. After that switch, he dropped all other series and devoted himself solely to ''Nero''. From 1992 to 2002, he was aided by [[Dirk Stallaert]], a young Flemish comic artist, and at first the intention was to let Stallaert continue the series after Marc Sleen retired. But in the end, Stallaert didn't feel ready to continue it alone, and at the end of 2002, at the age of 80, Marc Sleen ended his career as a comics artist. Sleen designed album covers for records by Flemish actor, comedian and singer [[Jef Burm]].{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Jef-Burm-Allo-Sjoe/release/5881518|title=Jef Burm - Allo Sjoe|publisher=}} Burm was a former school mate of his.{{cite web |url=http://www.sint-niklaas.be/nieuws/sint-niklaas-in-de-ban-van-het-b-gevaar |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-11-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160918004903/http://www.sint-niklaas.be/nieuws/sint-niklaas-in-de-ban-van-het-b-gevaar |archivedate=18 September 2016 |df=dmy-all }} ==TV documentary work== Marc Sleen was also known as a traveller and animal friend. He made 35 [[safari]]s to Africa between 1961 and 1991, making more than 20 documentaries for the [[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroep]], mostly for the TV show ''"Allemaal Beestjes"''. A few books and records about his safaris appeared as well. Many of his comics featured animals and countries he has visited. ==Legacy== Marc Sleen is commonly considered one of the big names of the Flemish comics, together with [[Willy Vandersteen]] and [[Jef Nys]]. In 2005 he was selected as one of the 111 nominees for the title "The Greatest Belgian" ([[De Grootste Belg]]) in the Flemish edition. He ended in 48th place. On June 19, 2009, a museum dedicated to his life and career was opened in Brussels: the [[Marc Sleen Museum]]. Both Marc Sleen as well as King [[Albert II of Belgium]] were present. The king was a fan of ''Nero'' since his youth and both he and [[Baudouin of Belgium]] learned Dutch by reading "Nero".{{cite news|last1=Ruell|first1=Niels|title=Marc Sleen Museum ingehuldigd|url=http://www.bruzz.be/nl/nieuws/marc-sleen-museum-ingehuldigd|accessdate=7 November 2016|publisher=Bruzz|date=18 June 2009|language=Dutch}} Sleen died at the age of 93 on the evening of November 6, 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.standaard.be/cnt/dmf20161107_02559483|title=Striptekenaar Marc Sleen is overleden|publisher=}} He was buried in the [[Campo Santo, Ghent|Campo Santo]] in Ghent.{{cite web|url=http://deredactie.be/cm/vrtnieuws/cultuur+en+media/kunsten/2.47499?eid=1.2814532|title=Marc Sleen|publisher=}} ==Awards== [[File:Hoeilaart station Nero beeld -2.JPG|thumb|Statue of [[Nero (comic book character)|Nero]] in [[Hoeilaart]]. It was specifically placed in front of the old train station (nowadays a bar), because this is Nero's home in the series since the album ''De Verschrikkelijke Tweeling'' (''The Horrible Twin'' (1990)). Sleen also lived in Hoeilaart.{{cite web|url=https://www.hoeilaart.be/nero|title=Nero|date=16 March 2015|publisher=}}]] * 1974: [[Prix Saint-Michel]] for best comical story, [[Brussels]], Belgium. The award went to ''Het Lachvirus'' (''The Laughing Virus''). * 1981: Honorary citizen of [[Hulshout]], Belgium * 1984: Honorary citizen of [[Sint-Niklaas]], Belgium * 1989: Stamp of Nero issued by the Belgian Post. * 1993: [[Bronzen Adhemar|Gouden Adhemar]] at [[Strip Turnhout]], Belgium * 1995: Best comic of 1994 by the "Belgische Kamer van stripexperten" (Belgian assembly of comic experts) * 1997: Knighted ([[Ridder (title)|Ridder]]) by [[monarch|king]] [[Albert II of Belgium]] * 2005: Honorary citizen of Brussels * 2008: Honorary citizen of [[Turnhout]] * 2011: Honorary citizen of [[Hoeilaart]]{{cite news|title=Striptekenaar Marc Sleen wordt ereburger van Hoeilaart|url=http://www.standaard.be/artikel/detail.aspx?artikelid=DMF20110526_072|accessdate=27 May 2011|newspaper=De Standaard|date=26 May 2011|language=Dutch}} Statues of his creations have been erected in [[Turnhout]] (1991), Hoeilaart (1994) and [[Middelkerke]] (1997). An exclusive museum opposite the [[Belgian Centre for Comic Strip Art]] is devoted to his work [https://web.archive.org/web/20110128073127/http://www.marc-sleen.be/en/marc-sleen-museum/presentation]. ==Major comics series== His comics were drawn rapidly in a "flexible and loose" style.{{cite web|title=Les murs de la promenade BD en détail|url=https://visit.brussels/fr/article/Les-murs-de-la-promenade-BD-en-detail|website=Visit Brussels|accessdate=9 November 2016|language=French|quote=un style de dessin souple et relâché}} They can be divided in one-page or one-strip gag series like ''Piet Fluwijn'' and ''De Lustige Kapoentjes'', and humorous adventure comics of book length (generally between 32 and 64 pages) like ''Stropke en Flopke'' and ''Nero''. * ''Piet Fluwijn'' (1944–1945) * ''[[Piet Fluwijn en Bolleke]]'' (1945–1965) (also known as ''The adventures of a father and his son'') * ''Pollopof'' (1946–1952) * ''Stropke en Flopke'' (1946–1950) * ''[[The Adventures of Nero|Nero]]'' (1947–2002) * ''[[De Ronde van Frankrijk]] ("the annual [[Tour de France]]". (Each year Marc Sleen drew a daily strip about the cycling event)'' (1947–1964) * ''[[De Lustige Kapoentjes]]'' (1950–1965) (continued by other artists including [[Hurey]] and [[Kabou]]) * ''[[Doris Dobbel]]'' (1950–1967) * ''Fonske'' (1951–1960) * ''[[Oktaaf Keunink]]'' (1952–1965) ==Notes== {{reflist|group=note}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Marc Sleen}} *[http://lambiek.net/artists/s/sleen.htm Marc Sleen] at [[Lambiek]] [[Comiclopedia]] {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2011}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sleen, Marc}} [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:Album-cover and concert-poster artists]] [[Category:Belgian comics artists]] [[Category:Belgian comics writers]] [[Category:Belgian cartoonists]] [[Category:Belgian caricaturists]] [[Category:Belgian documentary filmmakers]] [[Category:Belgian environmentalists]] [[Category:Belgian illustrators]] [[Category:Belgian knights]] [[Category:Belgian nature writers]] [[Category:Belgian satirists]] [[Category:Belgian television personalities]] [[Category:Breendonk concentration camp survivors]] [[Category:The Adventures of Nero]]

revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "A UK government committee composed of representatives from public-funded bodies who have a remit to undertake marine scientific research" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|A UK government committee composed of representatives from public-funded bodies who have a remit to undertake marine scientific research}} The '''Marine Science Co-ordination Committee''' ('''MSCC''') is a UK government committee composed of representatives from public-funded bodies who have a remit to undertake marine scientific research. There are also three non-executive members. The role of the MSCC is to implement the pan-UK Marine Science Strategy,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defra.gov.uk/environment/marine/documents/science/mscc/mscc-strategy.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-02-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205114931/http://www.defra.gov.uk/environment/marine/documents/science/mscc/mscc-strategy.pdf |archivedate=2010-12-05 |df= }}</ref> which covers the period 2010-2025. The secretariat for the MSCC is hosted by the Department of Environment, Food and Rural Affairs ([[Defra]]) and the [[Natural Environment Research Council]]'s [[National Oceanography Centre]].
The committee usually meets twice per year and was formed in 2008 in response to the recommendations of the House of Commons Select Committee Report 'Investigating the Oceans',<ref>{{cite web|url= https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200607/cmselect/cmsctech/470/470i.pdf|title= House of Commons Science and Technology Committee Investigating the Oceans}}</ref>and replaces the Inter-Agency Committee on Marine Science and Technology (IACMST).
The Marine Science Co-ordination Committee's work is overseen by a Ministerial Marine Science Group, representing UK and Devolved Governments.
The MSCC also has oversight of the [[Marine Environmental Data and Information Network]] <ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.oceannet.org/|title= MEDIN_ Marine data}}</ref>(MEDIN) and the UK Underwater Sound Forum.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.defra.gov.uk/mscc/ MSCC home page] * [http://www.imarest.org IMarEST] * [http://www.noc.ac.uk National Oceanography Centre] * [http://www.nerc.ac.uk Natural Environment Research Council]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Marine Science Co-Ordination Committee Mscc}} [[Category:Government of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Natural Environment Research Council]] [[Category:Oceanography]] [[Category:Scientific organisations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2008 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Scientific organizations established in 2008]]

{{Infobox rock |name= Micrometeorite |type= |coordinates= |image= File:Micrometeorite.jpg |alt= |caption= Micrometerorite collected from the [[Antarctica|Antarctic]] snow. }}
A '''micrometeorite''' is essentially a [[micrometeoroid]] that has survived [[atmospheric entry|entry]] through [[atmosphere of Earth|Earth's atmosphere]]. The [[particle size|size]] of such a [[particle]] ranges from 50 [[micrometre|µm]] to 2 [[millimeter|mm]]. Usually found on [[Earth]]'s surface, micrometeorites differ from [[meteorites]] in that they are smaller in size, more abundant, and different in composition. They are a subset of [[cosmic dust]], which also includes the smaller [[interplanetary dust]] particles (IDPs).<ref name = "Brownlee1997"> {{Citation | last = Brownlee | first = D. E. | last2 = Bates | first2 = B. | last3 = Schramm | first3 = L. | title = The elemental composition of stony cosmic spherules | journal = Meteoritics and Planetary Science | volume = 32 | issue =2 | pages = 157–175 | date = 1997 | bibcode = 1997M&PS...32..157B | doi = 10.1111/j.1945-5100.1997.tb01257.x}} </ref>
Micrometeorites enter Earth's atmosphere at high [[velocity|velocities]] (at least 11 km/s) and undergo heating through [[drag (physics)|atmospheric friction]] and [[Compression (physics)|compression]]. Micrometeorites individually weigh between 10<sup>−9</sup> and 10<sup>−4</sup> g and collectively comprise most of the extraterrestrial material that has come to the present-day Earth.<ref name="Love"> {{Citation | last = Love | first = S. G. | last2 = Brownlee | first2 = D. E. | title = A direct measurement of the terrestrial mass accretion rate of cosmic dust | journal = Science | volume = 262 | pages = 550–553 | date = 1993 | doi = 10.1126/science.262.5133.550 | pmid = 17733236 | issue = 5133|bibcode = 1993Sci...262..550L }} </ref>
[[Fred Lawrence Whipple]] first coined the term "micro-meteorite" to describe dust-sized objects that fall to the Earth.<ref name="Whipple"> {{Citation | last = Whipple | first = Fred | title = The Theory of Micro-Meteorites | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | pages = 687–695 | date = 1950 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.36.12.687 | volume = 36 | issue = 12|bibcode = 1950PNAS...36..687W | pmid=16578350 | pmc=1063272}} </ref> Sometimes meteoroids and micrometeoroids entering the Earth's atmosphere are visible as [[Meteoroid#Meteor|meteors or "shooting stars"]], whether or not they reach the ground and survive as meteorites and micrometorites.
==Introduction== Micrometeorite (MM) textures vary as their original structural and mineral compositions are modified by the degree of heating that they experience entering the atmosphere—a function of their initial speed and angle of entry. They range from unmelted particles that retain their original [[mineralogy]] (Fig. 1 a, b), to partially melted particles (Fig. 1 c, d) to round melted cosmic spherules (Fig. 1 e, f, g, h, Fig. 2) some of which have lost a large portion of their mass through vaporization (Fig. 1 i). Classification is based on composition and degree of heating.<ref name ="Taylor2000"> {{Citation | last = Taylor | first = S. | last2 = Lever | first2 = J. H. | last3 = Harvey | first3 = R. P. | title = Numbers, Types and Compositions of an Unbiased Collection of Cosmic Spherules | journal = Meteoritics & Planetary Science | volume = 35 | issue =4 | pages = 651–666 | date = 2000 | bibcode = 2000M&PS...35..651T | doi = 10.1111/j.1945-5100.2000.tb01450.x}} </ref><ref name = "Genge"> {{Citation | last = Genge | first = M. J. | last2 = Engrand | first2 = C. | last3 = Gounelle | first3 = M. | last4 = Taylor | first4 = S. | title = The Classification of Micrometeorites | journal = Meteoritics & Planetary Science | volume = 43 | issue =3 | pages = 497–515 | date = 2008 | bibcode = 2008M&PS...43..497G | doi = 10.1111/j.1945-5100.2008.tb00668.x}} </ref>
[[File:Cross sections of different micrometeorite classes.jpg|thumb|250px|Figure 1. Cross sections of different micrometeorite classes: a) Fine-grained unmelted; b) Coarse-grained Unmelted; c) Scoriaceous; d) Relict-grain Bearing; e) Porphyritic; f) Barred olivine; g) Cryptocrystalline; h) Glass; i) CAT; j) G-type; k) I-type; and l) Single mineral. Except for G- and I-types all are silicate rich, called stony MMs. Scale bars are 50µm.]]
[[File:Light microscope images of stony cosmic spherules.png|250px|thumb|Figure 2. Light microscope images of stony cosmic spherules.]] The extraterrestrial origins of micrometeorites are determined by microanalyses that show that: *The metal they contain is similar to that found in meteorites.<ref name="Smales"> {{Citation | last = Smales | first = A. A. | author-link = | last2 = Mapper | first2 = D. | last3 = Wood | first3 = A. J. | title = Radioactivation analysis of "cosmic" and other magnetic spherules | journal = Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta | volume = 13 | issue =2–3 | pages = 123–126 | date = 1958 | doi = 10.1016/0016-7037(58)90043-7|bibcode = 1958GeCoA..13..123S }} </ref> *Some have [[wüstite]], a high-temperature iron oxide found in meteorite fusion crusts.<ref name = "Marvin"> {{Citation | last = Marvin | first = U. B. | last2 = Marvin | first2 = M. T. | title = Black, Magnetic Spherules from Pleistocene and Recent beach sands | journal = Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta | volume = 31 | issue =10 | pages = 1871–1884 | date = 1967 | bibcode = 1967GeCoA..31.1871E | doi = 10.1016/0016-7037(67)90128-7}} </ref> *Their silicate minerals have major and trace elements ratios similar to those in meteorites.<ref name = "Blanchard"> {{Citation | last = Blanchard | first = M. B. | last2 = Brownlee | first2 = D. E. | last3 = Bunch | first3 = T. E. | last4 = Hodge | first4 = P. W. | last5 = Kyte | first5 = F. T. | title = Meteoroid ablation spheres from deep-sea sediments | journal = Earth Planet. Sci. Lett. | volume = 46 | issue =2 | pages = 178–190 | date = 1980 | bibcode = 1980E&PSL..46..178B | doi = 10.1016/0012-821X(80)90004-7}} </ref><ref name = "Ganapathy"> {{Citation | last = Ganapathy | first = R. | last2 = Brownlee | first2 = D. E. | last3 = Hodge | first3 = T. E. | last4 = Hodge | first4 = P. W. | title = Silicate spherules from deep-sea sediments: Confirmation of extraterrestrial origin | journal = Science | volume = 201 | issue =4361 | pages = 1119–1121 | date = 1978 | bibcode = 1978Sci...201.1119G | doi = 10.1126/science.201.4361.1119 | pmid = 17830315}} </ref> *The abundances of cosmogenic manganese ([[Isotopes of manganese|<sup>53</sup>Mn]]) in iron spherules and of cosmogenic beryllium ([[Beryllium-10|<sup>10</sup>Be]]), aluminum ([[Aluminium-26|<sup>26</sup>Al]]), and solar [[neon]] isotope in stony MMs are extraterrestrial<ref name = "Raisbeck"> {{Citation | last = Raisbeck | first = G. M. | last2 = Yiou | first2 = F. | last3 = Bourles | first3 = D. | last4 = Maurette | first4 = M. | title = <sup>10</sup>Be and <sup>26</sup>Al in Greenland cosmic spherules: Evidence for irradiation in space as small objects and a probable [[comet]]ary origin | journal = Meteoritics | volume = 21 | issue = | pages = 487–488 | date = 1986|bibcode = 1986Metic..21..487R }} </ref><ref name = "Nishiizumi"> {{Citation | last = Nishiizumi | first = K. | author-link = | last2 = Arnold | first2 = J. R. | last3 = Brownlee | first3 = D. E. | title = <sup>10</sup>Be and <sup>26</sup>Al in individual cosmic spherules from Antarctica | journal = Meteoritics | volume = 30 | issue =6 | pages =728–732 | origyear = | date =1995 | doi = 10.1111/j.1945-5100.1995.tb01170.x |display-authors=etal| hdl =2060/19980213244 }} </ref> *The presence of pre-solar grains in some MMs<ref name = "Yada"> {{Citation | last = Yada | first = T. | last2 = Floss | first2 = C. | title = Stardust in Antarctic micrometeorites | journal = Meteoritics & Planetary Science | volume = 43 | issue =8 | pages = 1287–1298 | date = 2008 | doi = 10.1111/j.1945-5100.2008.tb00698.x |bibcode = 2008M&PS...43.1287Y |display-authors=etal}} </ref> and [[deuterium]] excesses in ultra-carbonaceous MMs<ref name ="Duprat"/> indicates that they are not only extraterrestrial but that some of their components formed before our [[solar system]].
An estimated 30,000 ± 20,000 [[tonnes]] per year (t/yr)<ref name="Love"/> of cosmic dust enters the upper atmosphere each year of which less than 10% (2700 ± 1400 t/yr) is estimated to reach the surface as particles.<ref name = "Taylor1998"/> Therefore, the mass of micrometeorites deposited is roughly 50 times higher than that estimated for meteorites, which represent approximately 50 t/yr,<ref name = "Zolensky"> {{Citation | last = Zolensky | first = M. | last2 = Bland | first2 = M. | last3 = Brown | first3 = P. | last4 = Halliday | first4 = I. | editor-last = Lauretta | editor-first = Dante S. | editor2-last = McSween | editor2-first = Harry Y. | contribution = Flux of extraterrestrial materials | title = Meteorites and the Early Solar System II | place = Tucson | publisher = University of Arizona Press | date = 2006}} </ref> and the huge number of particles entering the atmosphere each year (~10<sup>17</sup> > 10 µm) suggests that large MM collections contain particles from all dust producing objects in the Solar System including asteroids, comets, and fragments from our Moon and Mars. Large MM collections provide information on the size, composition, atmospheric heating effects and types of materials accreting on Earth while detailed studies of individual MMs give insights into their origin, the nature of the [[carbon]], [[amino acid]]s and pre-solar grains they contain.<ref> {{Citation | first = S. | last = Taylor | first2 = J.H. | last2 = Schmitz | editor-last = Peucker-Erhenbrink | editor-first = B. | editor2-last = Schmitz | editor2-first = B. | date = 2001 | title = Accretion of Extraterrestrial matter throughout Earth's history—Seeking unbiased collections of modern and ancient micrometeorites | pages = 205–219 | place = New York | publisher = Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers | bibcode = 2001aemt.book.....P | journal = Accretion of extraterrestrial matter throughout earth's history/ edited by Bernhard Peucker-Ehrenbrink and Birger Schmitz; New York: Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers | doi = 10.1007/978-1-4419-8694-8_12 | isbn = 978-1-4613-4668-5 }} </ref>
==Collection sites== Micrometeorites have been collected from deep-sea [[sediment]]s, sedimentary rocks and polar sediments; they are currently collected primarily from polar snow and ice. Because of their low concentrations on the Earth's surface, MMs are sought in environments that concentrate these materials relative to terrestrial particles.
===Ocean sediments=== Melted micrometeorites (cosmic spherules) were first collected from deep-sea sediments during the 1873 to 1876 [[Challenger expedition|expedition of HMS ''Challenger'']]. In 1891, Murray and Renard found "two groups [of micrometeorites]: first, black magnetic spherules, with or without a metallic nucleus; second, brown-coloured spherules resembling chondr(ul)es, with a crystalline structure".<ref name = "Murray & Renard 1891"> {{Citation | last = Murray | first = J. | last2 = Renard | first2 = A. F. | title = Report on the scientific results of the voyage of ''H.M.S. Challenger'' during the years 1873–76 | journal = Deep-Sea Deposits | pages = 327–336 | date = 1891}} </ref> In 1883, they suggested that these spherules were extraterrestrial because they were found far from terrestrial particle sources, they did not resemble magnetic spheres produced in furnaces of the time, and their [[Nickel-iron alloy|nickel-iron]] (Fe-Ni) metal cores did not resemble metallic iron found in volcanic rocks. The spherules were most abundant in slowly accumulating sediments, particularly red clays deposited below the [[carbonate compensation depth]], a finding that supported a meteoritic origin.<ref name = "Murray & Renard 1883"> {{Citation | last = Murray | first = J. | last2 = Renard | first2 = A. F. | title = On the microscopic characters of volcanic ashes and cosmic dust, and their distribution in deep-sea deposits | journal = Proceedings of the Royal Society | volume = 12 | place = Edinburgh | pages = 474–495 | date = 1883}} </ref> In addition to those spheres with Fe-Ni metal cores, some spherules larger than 300 µm contain a core of elements from the platinum group.<ref> {{Citation| last = Brownlee | first = D. E. | last2 = Bates | first2 = B. A. | last3 = Wheelock | first3 = M. M. | title = Extraterrestrial platinum group nuggets in deep-sea sediments | doi = 10.1038/309693a0 | volume = 309 | issue = 5970 | pages = 693–695 | journal = Nature | date = 1984-06-21 | url = http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v309/n5970/abs/309693a0.html | bibcode = 1984Natur.309..693B | postscript = }}</ref>
Since the first collection of HMS ''Challenger'', cosmic spherules have been recovered from ocean sediments using cores, box cores, clamshell grabbers, and magnetic sleds.<ref> {{Citation | last = Brunn | first = A. F. | last2 = Langer | first2 = E. | last3 = Pauly | first3 = H. | title = Magnetic particles found by raking the deep-sea bottom | journal = Deep-Sea Research | volume = 2 | issue =3 | pages = 230–246 | date = 1955 | doi = 10.1016/0146-6313(55)90027-7|bibcode = 1955DSR.....2..230B }} </ref> Among these a magnetic sled, called the "Cosmic Muck Rake", retrieved thousands of cosmic spherules from the top 10 cm of red clays on the [[Pacific Ocean]] floor.<ref> {{Citation | last = Brownlee | first = D. E. | last2 = Pilachowski | first2 = L. B. | last3 = Hodge | first3 = P. W. | title = Meteorite mining on the ocean floor (abstract) | journal = Lunar Planet. Sci. | volume = X | issue = | pages = 157–158 | date = 1979}} </ref>
===Terrestrial sediments=== Terrestrial sediments also contain micrometeorites. These have been found in samples that: *Have low [[sedimentation]] rates such as claystones<ref> {{Citation | last = Crozier | first = W. D. | title = Black, magnetic spherules in sediments | journal = Journal of Geophysical Research | volume = 65 | issue =9 | pages = 2971–2977 | date = 1960 | bibcode = 1960JGR....65.2971C | doi = 10.1029/JZ065i009p02971}} </ref> and [[hardgrounds]]<ref name = "Czajkowski"> {{Citation | last = Czajkowski | first = J. | author-link = | last2 = Englert | first2 = P. | last3 = Bosellini | first3 = A. | last4 = Ogg | first4 = J. G. | title = Cobalt enriched hardgrounds-new sources of ancient extraterrestrial materials | journal = Meteoritics | volume = 18 | issue = | pages = 286–287 | date = 1983|bibcode = 1983Metic..18..286C }} </ref><ref> {{Citation | last = Jehanno | first = C. | author-link = | last2 = Boclet | first2 = D. | last3 = Bonte | first3 = Ph. | last4 = Castellarin | first4 = A. | last5 = Rocchia | first5 = R. | title = Identification of two populations of extraterrestrial particles in a Jurassic hardground of the Southern Alps | journal = Proc. Lun. Planet. Sci. Conf. | volume = 18 | issue = | pages = 623–630 | date = 1988 | bibcode = 1988LPSC...18..623J}} </ref> *Are easily dissolved such as [[salt deposit]]s<ref> {{Citation | last = Mutch | first = T.A. | title = Abundance of magnetic spherules in Silurian and Permian salt samples | journal = Earth and Planetary Science Letters | volume = 1 | issue =5 | pages = 325–329 | date = 1966 | bibcode = 1966E&PSL...1..325M | doi = 10.1016/0012-821X(66)90016-1}} </ref> and [[limestone]]s<ref> {{Citation | last = Taylor | first = S. | last2 = Brownlee | first2 = D. E. | title = Cosmic spherules in the geologic record | journal = Meteoritics | volume = 26 | issue =3 | pages = 203–211 | date = 1991 | bibcode = 1991Metic..26..203T | doi = 10.1111/j.1945-5100.1991.tb01040.x}} </ref> *Have been mass sorted such as heavy mineral concentrates found in deserts<ref> {{Citation | last = Fredriksson | first = K. | last2 = Gowdy | first2 = R. | title = Meteoritic debris from the Southern California desert | journal = Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta | volume = 27 | issue =3 | pages = 241–243 | date = 1963 | bibcode = 1963GeCoA..27..241F | doi = 10.1016/0016-7037(63)90025-5}} </ref> and beach sands.<ref name = "Marvin"/> The oldest MMs are totally altered iron spherules found in 140- to 180-million-year-old hardgrounds.<ref name = "Czajkowski"/>
Amateur collectors may find micrometeorites in areas where dirt and dust from a large area has been concentrated, such as from a roof downspout.<ref> {{cite web | last = Muhs | first = Eric | authorlink = | title = Micrometeorites | work = Ice Cube—South Pole Neutrino Laboratory | publisher = University of Wisconsin at River Falls Physics Department | date = | url = http://icecube.wisc.edu/outreach/activity/micrometeorites | accessdate = 2015-04-19}}</ref>
===Polar depositions=== [[File:SPWW.webmhd.webm|thumb|Click here to see a seven-minute movie of MMs being collected from the bottom of the South Pole drinking water well.|250px]] Micrometeorites found in polar sediments are much less weathered than those found in other terrestrial environments, as evidenced by little etching of interstitial glass, and the presence of large numbers of glass spherules and unmelted micrometeorites, particle types that are rare or absent in deep-sea samples.<ref name ="Taylor2000"/> The MMs found in polar regions have been collected from Greenland snow,<ref> {{Citation | last = Langway | first = C. C. | title = Sampling for extra-terrestrial dust on the Greenland Ice Sheet | journal = Union Geodesique et Geophysique Internationale, Association Internationale d'Hydrologie Scientific | volume = 61 | place = Berkeley Symposium | issue = | pages = 189–197 | date = 1963}} </ref> Greenland cryoconite,<ref> {{Citation | last = Wulfing | first = E. ==Classification and origins of micrometeorites==
===Classification=== Modern [[Meteorite#Meteorite types|classification of meteorites]] and micrometeorites is complex; the 2007 review paper of Krot et al.<ref name="Krot:2007"> {{Citation |volume=1 |title=Treatise on Geochemistry |chapter=1.05 Classification of Meteorites |doi=10.1016/B0-08-043751-6/01062-8 |isbn=978-0-08-043751-4 |first1=A. N. |last1=Krot |first2=K. |last2=Keil |first3=E. R. D. |last3=Scott |first4=C. A. |last4=Goodrich |first5=M. K. |last5=Weisberg |editor1-last=Holland |editor1-first=Heinrich D. |editor2-first=Karl K. |editor2-last=Turekian |pages=83–128 |publisher=Elsevier Ltd |date=2007}}</ref> summarizes modern meteorite taxonomy. Linking individual micrometeorites to meteorite classification groups requires a comparison of their elemental, isotopic and textural characteristics.<ref name = "Genge 2008"> {{Citation | last = Genge | first = M. J. | last2 = Engrand | first2 = C. | last3 = Gounelle | first3= M. | last4 = Taylor | first4 = S. | title = The classification of micrometeorites | journal = Meteoritics & Planetary Science | volume = 43 | issue = 3 | pages = 497–515 | origyear = | date = 2008 | url = http://www2.mnhn.fr/hdt205/leme/doc/2008%20Genge%20et%20al.%20MAPS.pdf | accessdate = 2013-01-13 | bibcode = 2008M&PS...43..497G | doi = 10.1111/j.1945-5100.2008.tb00668.x}} </ref>
===Comet vs asteroid origin of micrometeorites=== Whereas most meteorites likely originate from [[asteroids]], the contrasting makeup of micrometeorites suggests that most originate from [[comets]].
Fewer than 1% of MMs are [[Achondrite|achondritic]] and are similar to [[HED meteorites]], which are thought to be from the asteroid, [[4 Vesta]].<ref> {{Citation | last = Taylor | first = S. | last2 = Herzog | first2 = G. F. | last3 = Delaney | first3 = J. S. | title = Crumbs from the crust of Vesta: Achondritic cosmic spherules from the South Pole water well | journal = Meteoritics & Planetary Science | volume = 42 | issue =2 | pages = 223–233 | date = 2007 | bibcode = 2007M&PS...42..223T | doi = 10.1111/j.1945-5100.2007.tb00229.x}} </ref><ref> {{Citation | last = Cordier | first = C. | last2 = Folco | first2 = L. | last3 = Taylor | first3 = S. | title = Vestoid cosmic spherules from the South Pole Water Well and Transantarctic Mountains (Antarctica): A major and trace element study | journal = Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta | volume = 75 | issue =5 | pages = 1199–1215 | date = 2011 | bibcode = 2011GeCoA..75.1199C | doi = 10.1016/j.gca.2010.11.024}} </ref> Most MMs are compositionally similar to [[carbonaceous chondrite]]s,<ref> {{Citation | last = Kurat | first = G. | last2 = Koeberl | first2 = C. | last3 = Presper | first3 = T. | last4 = Brandstätter | title = Petrology and geochemistry of Antarctic micrometeorites | journal = Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta | volume = 58 | issue =18 | pages = 3879–3904 | date = 1994 | bibcode = 1994GeCoA..58.3879K | first4 = Franz | last5 = Maurette | first5 = Michel | doi = 10.1016/0016-7037(94)90369-7}} </ref><ref> {{Citation | last = Beckerling | first = W. | last2 = Bischoff | first2 = A. | title = Occurrence and composition of relict minerals in micrometeorites from Greenland and Antarctica—implications for their origins | journal = Planetary and Space Science | volume = 43 | issue =3–4 | pages = 435–449 | date = 1995 | doi = 10.1016/0032-0633(94)00175-Q|bibcode = 1995P&SS...43..435B }} </ref><ref> {{Citation | last = Greshake | first = A. | last2 = Kloeck | first2 =W. | last3 = Arndt | first3 = P. | last4 = Maetz | title = Heating experiments simulating atmospheric entry heating of micrometeorites: Clues to their parent body sources | journal = Meteoritics & Planetary Science | volume = 33 | issue =2 | pages = 267–290 | date = 1998 | bibcode = 1998M&PS...33..267G | first4 = Mischa | last5 = Flynn | first5 = George J. | last6 = Bajt | first6 = Sasa | last7 = Bischoff | first7 = Addi | doi = 10.1111/j.1945-5100.1998.tb01632.x}} </ref> whereas approximately 3% of meteorites are of this type.<ref> {{Citation | last = Sears | first = D. W. G. | title =The Case for Rarity of Chondrules and Calcium-Aluminum-rich Inclusions in the Early Solar System and Some Implications for Astrophysical Models | journal = Astrophysical Journal | volume = 498 | issue =2 | pages = 773–778 | date = 1998 | bibcode = 1998ApJ...498..773S | doi = 10.1086/305589}} </ref> The dominance of carbonaceous chondrite-like MMs and their low abundance in meteorite collections suggests that most MMs derive from sources different than those for most meteorites. Since most meteorites probably derive from asteroids, an alternative source for MMs might be comets. The idea that MMs might originate from comets originated in 1950.<ref name="Whipple"/>
Until recently the greater-than-25-km/s entry velocities of micrometeoroids, measured for particles from comet streams, cast doubts against their survival as MMs.<ref name = "Raisbeck"/><ref> {{Citation | last = Engrand | first = C. | last2 =Maurette | first2 = M. | title = Carbonaceous micrometeorites from Antarctica | journal = Meteoritics & Planetary Science | volume =33 | issue =4 | pages = 565–580 | date = 1998 | doi = 10.1111/j.1945-5100.1998.tb01665.x|bibcode = 1998M&PS...33..565E }} </ref> However, recent dynamical simulations<ref> {{Citation | last = Nesvorny | first = D. | last2 = Jenniskens | first2 = P. | last3 = Levison | first3 =H. F. | last4 = Bottke | title = Cometary origin of the zodiacal cloud and carbonaceous micrometeorites. Implications for hot debris disks | journal = The Astrophysical Journal | volume = 713 | issue =2 | pages = 816–836 | date = 2010 | bibcode = 2010ApJ...713..816N | first4 = William F. | last5 = Vokrouhlický | first5 = David | last6 = Gounelle | first6 = Matthieu | doi = 10.1088/0004-637X/713/2/816|arxiv = 0909.4322 }} </ref> suggest that 85% of cosmic dust could be cometary. Furthermore, analyses of particles returned from the comet, [[Wild 2]], by the [[Stardust (spacecraft)|''Stardust'' spacecraft]] show that these particles have compositions that are consistent with many micrometeorites.<ref> {{Citation | last = Brownlee | first = D. E. | last2 = Tsou | title = Comet 81P/Wild 2 Under a Microscope | journal = Science | volume = 314 | issue =5806 | pages = 1711–1716 | date = 2006 | bibcode = 2006Sci...314.1711B | first2 = Peter | last3 = Aléon | first3 = Jérôme | last4 = Alexander | first4 = Conel M. O.'D. | last5 = Araki | first5 = Tohru | last6 = Bajt | first6 = Sasa | last7 = Baratta | first7 = Giuseppe A. | last8 = Bastien | first8 = Ron | last9 = Bland | first9 = Phil | last10 = Bleuet | first10 = P. | last11 = Borg | first11 = J. | last12 = Bradley | first12 = J. P. | last13 = Brearley | first13 = A. | last14 = Brenker | first14 = F. | last15 = Brennan | first15 = S. | last16 = Bridges | first16 = J. C. | last17 = Browning | first17 = N. D. | last18 = Brucato | first18 = J. R. | last19 = Bullock | first19 = E. | last20 = Burchell | first20 = M. J. | last21 = Busemann | first21 = H. | last22 = Butterworth | first22 = A. | last23 = Chaussidon | first23 = M. | last24 = Cheuvront | first24 = A. | last25 = Chi | first25 = M. | last26 = Cintala | first26 = M. J. | last29 = Cody | first29 = G. | last30 = Colangeli | first30 = L. | doi = 10.1126/science.1135840 | pmid = 17170289| display-authors = 8 }} </ref><ref> {{Citation | last = Joswiak | first = D. J. | last2 = Brownlee | first2 = D. E. | last3 = Matrajt | first3 = G. | last4 = Westphal | title = Comprehensive examination of large mineral and rock fragments in Stardust tracks: Mineralogy, analogous extraterrestrial materials, and source regions | journal = Meteoritics & Planetary Science | volume = 47 | issue =4 | pages = 471–524 | date = 2012 | bibcode = 2012M&PS...47..471J | first4 = Andrew J. | last5 = Snead | first5 = Christopher J. | last6 = Gainsforth | first6 = Zack | doi = 10.1111/j.1945-5100.2012.01337.x}} </ref> Nonetheless, some parent bodies of micrometeorites appear to be asteroids with [[chondrule]]-bearing carbonaceous [[chondrites]].<ref name = "Genge 2005"> {{Citation | last = Genge | first = M. J. | last2 = Gileski | first2 = A. | last3 = Grady | first3 = M. M. | title = Chondrules in Antarctic micrometeorites | journal = Meteoritics & Planetary Science | volume = 40 | issue = 2 | pages = 225–238 | date = 2005 | language = | url = http://www3.imperial.ac.uk/pls/portallive/docs/1/6831910.PDF | accessdate = 2013-01-13 | archiveurl = | bibcode = 2005M&PS...40..225G | doi = 10.1111/j.1945-5100.2005.tb00377.x}} </ref>
==Extraterrestrial micrometeorites== The influx of micrometeoroids also contributes to the composition of [[regolith]] (planetary/lunar soil) on other bodies in the Solar System. [[Mars]] has an estimated annual micrometeoroid influx of between 2,700 and 59,000 t/yr. This contributes to about 1m of micrometeoritic content to the depth of the Martian regolith every billion years. Measurements from the [[Viking program]] indicate that the Martian regolith is composed of 60% basaltic rock and 40% rock of meteoritic origin. The lower-density Martian atmosphere allows much larger particles than on Earth to survive the passage through to the surface, largely unaltered until impact. While on Earth particles that survive entry typically have undergone significant transformation, a significant fraction of particles entering the Martian atmosphere throughout the 60 to 1200-μm diameter range probably survive unmelted.<ref name="Flynn 1990">{{Citation|last=Flynn|first=George J.|author2=McKay, David S.|title=An assessment of the meteoritic contribution to the martian soil|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research|date=1 January 1990|volume=95|issue=B9|pages=14497|doi=10.1029/JB095iB09p14497|bibcode = 1990JGR....9514497F }}</ref>

{{Infobox Government agency | agency_name = Ministry of Water and Power | nativename ={{nq|وزارت پانی و بجلی}} | nativename_a = | nativename_r = | logo = | logo_width = | logo_caption = | seal = Coat of arms of Pakistan.svg | seal_width = 140px | seal_caption = Seal of Government of Pakistan | formed = {{Start date and years ago|1947|8|14}} | preceding1 = | preceding2 = | dissolved = August 2017 | superseding = | jurisdiction = Pakistan |headquarters = Block A, [[Pak Secretariat]]
[[Islamabad]], [[Islamabad Capital Territory|ICT]], [[Pakistan]]. 44000. | coordinates = | region_code = | employees = | budget = | chief1_position = | chief1_name = | chief2_position = | chief2_name = | chief3_position = | chief3_name = | website = {{URL|http://www.mowp.gov.pk/|Official Website}} | footnotes = }} The '''Ministry of Water and Power''' ({{lang-ur|{{nq|'''وزارت پانی و بجلی'''}}}}, abbreviated as '''MoPW''') was a [[Central government|federal]] [[Ministry (government department)|ministry]] in [[Pakistan]]. The ministry was dissolved in August 2017. The water division was merged with newly created Ministry of Water Resources and the power division was moved under [[Ministry of Energy (Pakistan)|Ministry of Energy]].{{cite news|title=Pakistan PM creates new ministries|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/story/559153/Pakistan-PM-creates-new-ministries|accessdate=6 August 2017|work=Gulf-Times|date=6 August 2017|language=ar}} ==Companies/ Divisions== ===Water and Power Development Authority=== {{main|Water and Power Development Authority}} ===National Transmission And Despatch Company=== NTDC is a limited company established in 1998. The main function of company is to purchase electric power from [[List of power stations in Pakistan|generation companies]] and then sells to [[List of electric supply companies in Pakistan|distribution companies]].http://www.ntdc.com.pk/CompanyProfile.php ===Federal Flood Commission=== {{main|Federal Flood Commission}} The Federal Flood Commission (FFC) is an agency within the Ministry that was created in 1977 in response to severe flooding by the [[Indus River]]. The FFC has been charged to execute flood control projects and protect lives and property from the impact of floods. By 2010 the FFC had received Rs 87.8 billion since its inception, and its own documents demonstrate that numerous projects were initiated, paid for, and seemingly completed. However, after the devastating [[2010 Pakistan floods]] the agency has been severely criticized as apparently very little actual work had been done on the ground and it was accused of ineffectiveness and corruption. {{cite news|url=http://www.nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/Politics/19-Aug-2010/Heavily-funded-FFC-fails-to-deliver/|first=Ahmad|last=Ahmadani|title=Heavily funded FFC fails to deliver|newspaper=[[The Nation (Pakistan)]]|date=19 August 2010|accessdate=2 June 2012}} ===Private Power and Infrastructure Board=== The Private Power and Infrastructure Board (PPIB) was created in 1994 to promote [[private sector]] participation in the [[Energy in Pakistan|power sector of Pakistan]].http://www.nation.com.pk/islamabad/01-Feb-2012/senate-passes-private-power-infrastructure-board-bill PPIB facilitates investors in establishing private power projects and related infrastructure, executes Implementation Agreement (IA) with Project Sponsors and issues sovereign guarantees on behalf of [[Federal Government of Pakistan|government]].http://www.ppib.gov.pk/N_about_ppib.htmhttp://pakistanlegal.blogspot.com/2012/04/private-power-and-infrastructure-board.html ===Alternative Energy Development Board=== {{short description|The thermal motion of liquid or gas particles at temperatures above absolute zero }} {{About|spontaneous dispersion of mass|a more generic treatment of diffusion|Diffusion}} [[File:DiffusionMicroMacro.gif|thumb|260px|Diffusion from a microscopic and macroscopic point of view. Initially, there are [[solution|solute]] molecules on the left side of a barrier (purple line) and none on the right. The barrier is removed, and the solute diffuses to fill the whole container. <u>Top:</u> A single molecule moves around randomly. <u>Middle:</u> With more molecules, there is a clear trend where the solute fills the container more and more uniformly. <u>Bottom:</u> With an enormous number of solute molecules, all randomness is gone: The solute appears to move smoothly and systematically from high-concentration areas to low-concentration areas, following Fick's laws.]]
'''Molecular diffusion''', often simply called '''diffusion''', is the thermal motion of all (liquid or gas) particles at [[temperature]]s above [[absolute zero]]. The rate of this movement is a function of temperature, [[viscosity]] of the fluid and the size (mass) of the particles. Diffusion explains the net [[flux]] of molecules from a region of higher concentration to one of lower concentration. Once the concentrations are equal the molecules continue to move, but since there is no concentration gradient the process of molecular diffusion has ceased and is instead governed by the process of [[self-diffusion]], originating from the random motion of the molecules. The result of diffusion is a gradual mixing of material such that the distribution of molecules is uniform. Since the molecules are still in motion, but an equilibrium has been established, the end result of molecular diffusion is called a "dynamic equilibrium". In a [[Phase (matter)|phase]] with uniform temperature, absent external net forces acting on the particles, the diffusion process will eventually result in complete mixing.
Consider two systems; S<sub>1</sub> and S<sub>2</sub> at the same [[temperature]] and capable of exchanging [[Molecule|particles]]. If there is a change in the [[potential energy]] of a system; for example μ<sub>1</sub>>μ<sub>2</sub> (μ is [[Chemical potential]]) an [[energy]] flow will occur from S<sub>1</sub> to S<sub>2</sub>, because nature always prefers low energy and maximum [[entropy]].
Molecular diffusion is typically described mathematically using [[Fick's laws of diffusion]].
== Applications == Diffusion is of fundamental importance in many disciplines of physics, chemistry, and biology. Some example applications of diffusion: * [[Sintering]] to produce solid materials ([[powder metallurgy]], production of [[ceramic]]s) * [[Chemical reactor]] design * [[Catalysis|Catalyst]] design in chemical industry * [[Steel]] can be diffused (e.g., with carbon or nitrogen) to modify its properties * [[Doping (semiconductor)|Doping]] during production of [[semiconductor]]s.
== Significance == [[File:Diffusion (1).png|thumb|280px|Schematic representation of mixing of two substances by diffusion]] Diffusion is part of the [[transport phenomena]]. Of mass transport mechanisms, molecular diffusion is known as a slower one.
=== Biology === In [[cell biology]], diffusion is a main form of transport for necessary materials such as [[amino acid]]s within cells.<ref>{{cite book | last = Maton | first = Anthea | authorlink = |author2=Jean Hopkins |author3=Susan Johnson |author4=David LaHart |author5=Maryanna Quon Warner |author6=Jill D. Wright | title = Cells Building Blocks of Life | publisher = Prentice Hall | year = 1997 | location = Upper Saddle River, New Jersey | pages = 66–67 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = }}</ref> Diffusion of solvents, such as water, through a [[semipermeable membrane]] is classified as [[osmosis]].
[[Metabolism]] and [[Respiration (physiology)|respiration]] rely in part upon diffusion in addition to bulk or active processes. For example, in the [[pulmonary alveolus|alveoli]] of [[mammal]]ian [[lung]]s, due to differences in partial pressures across the alveolar-capillary membrane, [[oxygen]] diffuses into the blood and [[carbon dioxide]] diffuses out. Lungs contain a large surface area to facilitate this gas exchange process.
== Tracer, self- and chemical diffusion == [[File:Diffusion self1.svg|thumb|340px|Self diffusion, exemplified with an isotopic tracer of radioactive isotope <sup>22</sup>Na]] [[File:Diffusion4.svg|thumb|340px|Example of chemical (classical, Fick's, or Fickian) diffusion of sodium chloride in water]] <!-- "Wasser" should be "Water" in second figure. -->Fundamentally, two types of diffusion are distinguished: * ''Tracer diffusion'' and ''Self-diffusion'', which is a spontaneous mixing of molecules taking place in the absence of concentration (or chemical potential) gradient. This type of diffusion can be followed using [[Isotopic labeling|isotopic tracers]], hence the name. The tracer diffusion is usually assumed to be identical to [[self-diffusion]] (assuming no significant [[Kinetic isotope effect|isotopic effect]]). This diffusion can take place under equilibrium. An excellent method for the measurement of [[self-diffusion]] coefficients is [[pulsed field gradient]] (PFG) [[NMR]], where no isotopic tracers are needed. In a so-called NMR [[spin echo]] experiment this technique uses the nuclear spin precession phase, allowing to distinguish chemically and physically completely identical species e.g. in the liquid phase, as for example water molecules within liquid water. The self-diffusion coefficient of water has been experimentally determined with high accuracy and thus serves often as a reference value for measurements on other liquids. The self-diffusion coefficient of neat water is: 2.299·10<sup>−9</sup> m²·s<sup>−1</sup> at 25 °C and 1.261·10<sup>−9</sup> m²·s<sup>−1</sup> at 4 °C.<ref name =wasser>M. Holz, S.R. Heil, A. Sacco: ''Temperature-dependent self-diffusion coefficients of water and six selected molecular liquids for calibration in accurate 1H NMR PFG Measurements.'' In: ''Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys.'' '''2''',4740–4742 (2000).</ref> * ''Chemical diffusion'' occurs in a presence of concentration (or chemical potential) gradient and it results in net transport of mass. This is the process described by the diffusion equation. This diffusion is always a non-equilibrium process, increases the system entropy, and brings the system closer to equilibrium.
The [[Mass diffusivity|diffusion coefficient]]s for these two types of diffusion are generally different because the diffusion coefficient for chemical diffusion is binary and it includes the effects due to the correlation of the movement of the different diffusing species.
== Non-equilibrium system == [[File:entropie.svg|thumb|280px|Illustration of low entropy (top) and high entropy (bottom)]] Because chemical diffusion is a net transport process, the system in which it takes place is not an [[chemical equilibrium|equilibrium]] system (i.e. it is not at rest yet). Many results in classical thermodynamics are not easily applied to non-equilibrium systems. However, there sometimes occur so-called quasi-steady states, where the diffusion process does not change in time, where classical results may locally apply. As the name suggests, this process is a not a true equilibrium since the system is still evolving.
Non-equilibrium fluid systems can be successfully modeled with Landau-Lifshitz fluctuating hydrodynamics. In this theoretical framework, diffusion is due to fluctuations whose dimensions range from the molecular scale to the macroscopic scale.<ref>D. Brogioli and A. Vailati, ''[https://arxiv.org/abs/cond-mat/0006163 Diffusive mass transfer by nonequilibrium fluctuations: Fick's law revisited]'', Phys. Rev. E '''63''', 012105/1-4 (2001)</ref>
Chemical diffusion increases the [[entropy]] of a system, i.e. diffusion is a spontaneous and irreversible process. Particles can spread out by diffusion, but will not spontaneously re-order themselves (absent changes to the system, assuming no creation of new chemical bonds, and absent external forces acting on the particle).
== Concentration dependent "collective" diffusion == ''Collective diffusion'' is the diffusion of a large number of particles, most often within a [[solvent]].
Contrary to [[brownian motion]], which is the diffusion of a single particle, interactions between particles may have to be considered, unless the particles form an ideal mix with their solvent (ideal mix conditions correspond to the case where the interactions between the solvent and particles are identical to the interactions between particles and the interactions between solvent molecules; in this case, the particles do not interact when inside the solvent).
In case of an ideal mix, the particle [[diffusion equation]] holds true and the diffusion coefficient ''D'' the speed of [[diffusion]] in the particle diffusion equation is independent of particle concentration. In other cases, resulting interactions between particles within the solvent will account for the following effects: * the diffusion coefficient ''D'' in the particle diffusion equation becomes dependent of concentration. For an attractive interaction between particles, the diffusion coefficient tends to decrease as concentration increases. For a repulsive interaction between particles, the diffusion coefficient tends to increase as concentration increases. * In the case of an attractive interaction between particles, particles exhibit a tendency to coalesce and form clusters if their [[concentration]] lies above a certain threshold. This is equivalent to a [[Precipitation (chemistry)|precipitation]] chemical reaction (and if the considered diffusing particles are chemical molecules in solution, then it is a [[Precipitation (chemistry)|precipitation]]).
== Molecular diffusion of gases == Transport of material in stagnant fluid or across streamlines of a fluid in a laminar flow occurs by molecular diffusion. Two adjacent compartments separated by a partition, containing pure gases A or B may be envisaged. Random movement of all molecules occurs so that after a period molecules are found remote from their original positions. If the partition is removed, some molecules of A move towards the region occupied by B, their number depends on the number of molecules at the point considered. Concurrently, molecules of B diffuse toward regimens formerly occupied by pure A. Finally, complete mixing occurs. Before this point in time, a gradual variation in the concentration of A occurs along an axis, designated x, which joins the original compartments. This variation, expressed mathematically as -dC<sub>A</sub>/dx, where C<sub>A</sub> is the concentration of A. The negative sign arises because the concentration of A decreases as the distance x increases. Similarly, the variation in the concentration of gas B is -dC<sub>B</sub>/dx. The rate of diffusion of A, N<sub>A</sub>, depend on concentration gradient and the average velocity with which the molecules of A moves in the x direction. This relationship is expressed by [[Fick's Law]]
: <math>N_{A}= -D_{AB} \frac{dC_{A}}{dx}</math> (only applicable for no bulk motion)
where D is the Diffusivity of A through B, proportional to the average (squared?) molecular velocity and, therefore dependent on the temperature and pressure of gases. The rate of Diffusion N<sub>A</sub>,is usually expressed as the number of moles diffusing across unit area in unit time. As with the basic equation of heat transfer, this indicates that the rate of force is directly proportional to the driving force, which is the concentration gradient.
This basic equation applies to a number of situations. Restricting discussion exclusively to steady state conditions, in which neither dC<sub>A</sub>/dx or dC<sub>B</sub>/dx change with time, equimolecular counterdiffusion is considered first.
==Equimolecular counterdiffusion==
If no bulk flow occurs in an element of length dx, the rates of diffusion of two ideal gases (of similar molar volume) A and B must be equal and opposite, that is <math>N_A=-N_B</math>.
The partial pressure of A changes by dP<sub>A</sub> over the distance dx. Similarly, the partial pressure of B changes dP<sub>B</sub>. As there is no difference in total pressure across the element (no bulk flow), we have
:<math> \frac{dP_A}{dx}=-\frac{dP_B}{dx}</math>.
For an ideal gas the partial pressure is related to the molar concentration by the relation
:<math> P_{A}V=n_{A}RT</math>
where n<sub>A</sub> is the number of moles of gas ''A'' in a volume ''V''. As the molar concentration ''C<sub>A</sub>'' is equal to ''n<sub>A</sub>/ V'' therefore
:<math> P_{A}=C_{A}RT</math>
Consequently, for gas A,
:<math> N_{A}=-D_{AB} \frac{1}{RT} \frac{dP_{A}}{dx} </math>
where D<sub>AB</sub> is the diffusivity of A in B. Similarly,
:<math> N_{B}=-D_{BA} \frac{1}{RT} \frac{dP_{B}}{dx}=D_{AB} \frac{1}{RT}\frac{dP_{A}}{dx}</math>
Considering that dP<sub>A</sub>/dx=-dP<sub>B</sub>/dx, it therefore proves that D<sub>AB</sub>=D<sub>BA</sub>=D. If the partial pressure of A at x<sub>1</sub> is P<sub>A<sub>1</sub></sub> and x<sub>2</sub> is P<sub>A<sub>2</sub></sub>, integration of above equation,
:<math> N_{A}=-\frac{D}{RT} \frac{(P_{A2}-P_{A1})}{x_{2}-x_{1}}</math>
A similar equation may be derived for the counterdiffusion of gas B.

[[Western Australia]] has relatively few species of [[moss]]; the most recent census found just 192 taxa. This represents just 10% of [[Australia]]'s total moss flora, even though Western Australia accounts for about one third of the Australia by area. This relatively low diversity has been attributed to the lack of [[rainforest]] in the state.<ref name="Stoneburner 1993">{{cite journal |author1=Stoneburner, Ann |author2=Wyatt, Robert |author3=Catcheside, David |author4=Stone, Ilma |last-author-amp=yes | title = Census of the Mosses of Western Australia | journal = The Bryologist | volume = 96 | issue = 1 | year = 1993 | pages = 86–101 | doi = 10.2307/3243324 | publisher = The Bryologist, Vol. 96, No. 1 | jstor = 3243324}}</ref>
By far the majority of the state's moss species occur in the [[Southwest Botanical Province]], with over 80% of all species, genera and families occurring there. This includes four species that are apparently endemic to the province.<ref name="Stoneburner 1993"/>
About 70% of Western Australia's moss taxa occur also in [[South Australia]], and a similar proportion occur also in [[New South Wales]]. Only about 50% occur also in [[Queensland]]. About half are restricted to [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]] and [[South Africa]], and a further 10% occur also only in [[South America]].<ref name="Stoneburner 1993"/>
==List of mosses of Western Australia== This is a list of mosses of Western Australia,<ref name="Stoneburner 1993"/> with classification updated.<ref name="Buck & Goffinet">Buck, William R. & Bernard Goffinet. 2000. "Morphology and classification of mosses", pages 71-123 ''in'' A. Jonathan Shaw & Bernard Goffinet (Eds.), ''Bryophyte Biology''. (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press). {{ISBN|0-521-66097-1}}.</ref>

H. | year = 1993 | title = Genera of the Pottiaceae: Mosses of harsh environments | journal = Bulletin of the Buffalo Society of Natural History | volume = 32}}</ref> * ''[[Acaulon eremicola]]'' * ''[[Acaulon granulosum|A. granulosum]]'' * ''[[Acaulon integrifolium|A. integrifolium]]'' * ''[[Acaulon leucochaete|A. leucochaete]]'' * ''[[Acaulon mediterraneum|A. mediterraneum]]'' * ''[[Acaulon triquetrum|A. triquetrum]]'' * ''[[Aloina sullivaniana]]'' * ''[[Barbula calycina]]'' * ''[[Barbula crinita|B. crinita]]'' * ''[[Barbula ehrenbergii|B. ehrenbergii]]'' * ''[[Barbula hornschuchiana|B. hornschuchiana]]'' * ''[[Barbula indica|B. indica]]'' * ''[[Barbula luteola|B. luteola]]'' * ''[[Barbula subcalycina|B. subcalycina]]'' * ''[[Bryoerythrophyllum binnsii]]'' * ''[[Calymperastrum latifolium]]'' * ''[[Crossidium davidai]]'' * ''[[Crossidium geheebii|C. geheebii]]'' * ''[[Desmatodon recurvatus|D. recurvatus]]'' * ''[[Didymodon luehmannii]]'' * ''[[Didymodon subtorquatus|D. subtorquatus]]'' * ''[[Didymodon torquatus|D. torquatus]]'' * ''[[Gymnostomiella vernicosa]]'' * ''[[Gymnostomum calcareum]]'' * ''[[Hyophila involuta]]'' * ''[[Hyophila rosea|H. rosea]]'' * ''[[Leptodontium paradoxum]]'' * ''[[Phasconica balansae]]'' * ''[[Phascopsis rubicunda]]'' * ''[[Phascum laticostum]]'' * ''[[Phascum longipilum|P. longipilum]]'' * [[Phascum robustum var. crassinervium|''P. robustum'' var.
